editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Written by Mr WILLIAM CARTVVRIGHT, Late Student of Chriſt-Church in OXFORD, and Proctor of the Ʋniverſity.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moſeley, and are to be ſold at his ſhop at the Sign of the Princes Armes in St PAVLS Churchyard. 1651.

lg.l: SAcred to your Delight
Be the ſhort Revels of this Night;
That Calme that in yond Myrtles moves,
Crowne all your Thoughts, and Loves:
And as the fat all Yew-tree ſhews
No Spring among thoſe happy Boughs,
So be all Care quite baniſht hence
Whiles eaſie Quiet rocks your Sence.
We cannot here complain
Of want of Preſence, or of Train;
For if choice Beauties make the Court,
And their Light guild the Sport,
This honour'd Ring preſents us here
Glories as rich and freſh as there;
And it may under Queſtion fall,
Which is more Court, This, or White-Hall.
Be't ſo. But then the Face
Of what we bring fits not the Place,
And ſo we ſhall pull down what ere
Your Glories have built here:
Yet if you will conceive, that though
The Poem's forc'd, We are not ſo;
And that each Sex keeps to it's Part,
Nature may plead excuſe for Art.
As then there's no Offence
Giv'n to the Weak or Stubborn hence,
Being the Female's Habit is
Her owne; and the Male's his:
So (if great things may ſteer by leſs)
May you the ſame in looks expreſs:
Your Weare is Smiles, and Gracious Eyes;
When ere you frown 'tis but diſguiſe.

row.cell: Two Lords of Cyprus, the one Husband to Florina, the other to Malthora.
A young Lord of Cyprus, left at home by reaſon of ſickneſs.
Belonging to Apollo's Temple in Crete.
Two Ladies ſadly bearing the Abſenſe of their Lords.
Three buſie factious Ladies, and contrary to the two former.
A young Lady Confident to the Princeſs.

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Coſmeta, Pandena, (Rhodia between them) buſily diſcourſing in the Myrtle Grove.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: ANd if you ſee not Women plead, an judge,
Raiſe, and depreſs, reward, and puniſh, carry
Things how they pleaſe, and turn the Politique dore
Upon new hindges very ſhortly, never
Beleeve the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Could I ſee't 'twould prove
An Antidote againſt old Age, and make me
Grow younger ſtill without Expence or Art.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You ſin paſt pardon Rhodia, if you doubt it.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: The plot's moſt firm and ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The Means advis'd.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: The carriage hitherto ſucceſſefull; we
Gain daily to our ſide.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Doe they come in?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: As to a Marriage; Offer money, Plate,
Jewels, and Garments, nay the Images
Of their Male-Gods.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: The very name of Rule
Raiſes their Blouds, and makes 'em throw their Wealth
Away as heartily, as if they were
Young Heires, or old Philoſophers.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Why then,
There's one care ſav'd Coſmeta.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: What's that pray?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I was preparing ſtrong Preſervatives
Againſt our Lords came home, for fear of fainting
At their Arrivall.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: They'd have ſmelt indeed
Of Labour, Sweat, Duſt, Man, and Victory.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: And ſuch groſſe Ruſtick ſents, that a Court noſe
Without the patience of a Stoick, could not
Have poſſibly endur'd them,

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I believe
They'd have encreas'd the Bill, and ſome would weekly
Have dy'd of the Lords Return from the Cretan War:
What growth's your Plot of Madam?

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: O it ripens
Paſt expectation! See, Beſides our ſelves
Eleven Court. Ladies on the Roll already;
Hyantha then ſends word, that ten, or twelve
Very ſubſtantiall Countrey-Ladies have
Subſcrib'd three days ago.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: My Province here,
The City-wives, ſwarm in, ſtrive, and make means
Who ſhall command their Husbands firſt.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: And then
Of Countrey Gentlewomen, and their eldeſt daughters,
More than can write their Names; 'Tis now paſt danger.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: But, Madam, how'l you gain the men at home?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: For that brace & half of Courtiers there, Ganyctor,
Lerinus, and Iringus, they are mine,
Faſt in the Net, if I but pitch it only.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Look where they come, pray ſweare 'em preſently.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: I'Ll give 'em but my hand to kiſs, and 'twill
Bind 'em as faſt, as if it were the holieſt
Of the beſt Sibyls Leaves.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Favour your tongues;
Let's lie in Ambuſh here a while, and liſten
What they diſcourſe of.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Why of Women I warranty'.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: Peace Rhodia, peace, cloſe ſweet Pandena, cloſe!

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Lerinus, this hath been the worſt Spring that
I ever knew.

sp.speaker: Lorin.
sp.l: Faith it has', for Flora
Still challeng'd it before, but now Bellona
Hath got the time: Roſes and Violets were
The fruit o'th' Seaſon formerly, but now
Laying, and raiſing Sieges: Building up
And pulling down of Caſtles; Manning, and
Demoliſhing of Forts have ſign'd the Months.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Where beauteous Ladies ſlumber'd, & were guarded
By the enamor'd Lizards (as if Cadmus
In envy had reſerv'd ſome Serpents teeth
And ſown 'em there) hard watchings and rough Guards
Fill and make up the field.

sp.speaker: (Coſm.
sp.l: Moſt ſmoothly ſaid,
And like a Cowardly Poet.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: There's a feare
The Women too will riſe at home.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Their fingers
Itch to be tamp'ring with the wheels o'th' State.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: 'Tis very well my Lord Olyndus then
Is left at home.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: How does his Lordſhip now?
Still angry that his Majeſty would not let
His Sickneſs go againſt the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: He finds the hardeſt Wars at home, he hath
Viſits, and Onſets, that moleſt him more
Than all his griefs. He now complains of health;
The eager Ladyes do beſiege him hourly,
Not out of love ſo much, as want of men;
Any thing now, that wears but Breeches only,
Is plotted, and projected for as much
As a new Faſhion, or an Office 'bove Stairs,

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: They do call this their time of Perſecution,
Swear they are living Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Then the Puniſhment
Muſt make 'em ſo; I'm ſure the cauſe will never.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: A man is ſtriven for as eagerly
As the laſt loaf in a great depth of Famine.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: You won't believe what I ſhall tell you now;
Pandena and ſweet Rhodia at this inſtant
Both love me, hate each other, eager Rivals;
The one enſhrines her Mellons in pure Chryſtall,
And as the fruit doth ripen, ſo her hopes
Of me doe ripen with it—

sp.speaker: (Pan.
sp.l: Monſtrous fellow!)

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: The other counts her Apricots, and thinks
So many kiſses grow there; lays 'em naked
And open to the Sun, that it may freely
Smile on her vegetable Embraces.

sp.speaker: (Rho.
sp.l: Good! do you hear this, Madam?)

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Peace and let him on.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: The one preſents me, and the other preſents me
Gums, Spicknard-boxes, Fruits, and early Roſes,
Figs, Muſhrooms, Bulbi, and what not? I am
More reverenc'd than their Houſhold-God, and taſte
Their ſtore before him ſtill.

sp.speaker: (Coſm.
sp.l: Cloſe yet for my ſake.)

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: And proud Coſmeta—

sp.speaker: (Pan.
sp.l: Nay you muſt hear't out too.)

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: She, that, if there were Sexes 'bove the Moon,
VVould tempt a Male Idea, and ſeduce
A Separate Hee-Subſtance into Lewdneſs,
Hath ſmil'd, glanc'd, wink'd, and trod upon my toes,
Sent ſmooth Epiſtles to me, whom I let
Paſs unregarded, as a ſuing Beauty,
And one that makes my triumph up—
sp.stage: [As he ſpeaks Coſmeta and the other two Ladies approach.
sp.l: Fair Ladies
You make my Triumph up in that I ſee you.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: VVhat? have you been at the VVars then Captain?

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Madam
I've ſtood o'th' ſhore, and wiſht well to our Fleet.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: If that be all, pray how comes ſo much Creſt,
And Scarfe, and Boot to be miſplac'd on you?

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Is't not a time of VVar, dear Lady?

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.l: You follow
The times then, though you won't the Camp.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: 'Tis fit
VVe ſhould be in the Field-faſhion however.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: 'Cauſe you intend the VVars at home perhaps.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Troth the beleagering of you, Lady, will
Hardly deſerve the name of a Siedge; you'll yeeld
So eaſily on the firſt approach.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: You doe
Miſtake her, Sir, ſhe means, that you intend
To take great Towns at home—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Demoliſh Caſtles,
And high-built Pyes at once—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Gaine Sconces 'twixt
The firſt and ſecond Courſe—

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: And in the vertue
Of the large Cretan Jar kill men at Table.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: No Lady, we do ſtay at home to make 'em.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The Wars indeed 'll exhauſt the Kingdom much.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And fit tis that ſhould ſome way be ſupply'd.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: You won't corrupt me, Madam? pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: No, Sir, I will not do the State that harm;
For the Corruption of one Coward muſt
Needs be the Generation of another.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: I'll warrant th'Iſſue will be truly valiant.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And how ſo Captain Stay-by-it?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Madam, he
Can neither fight nor ſpeak: I'll tell you how.
That you're a Coward, Sir, is granted: Thus then;
Either your Father was valiant, or was not.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: A very ſure diviſion, Lady, that.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: If he were valiant, and you a Coward,
'Tis your Sons courſe next to be valiant;
But if he were not valiant, and that
You are a Coward of a Coward, then
Your Lineall Iſſue muſt be valiant needs,
Becauſe two Negatives make an Affirmative.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: A moſt invincible Argument!

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: This ſhall not
Serve I aſſure you, ſay what e're you will
You ſhall not reaſon me to your Bed-ſide.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Not though we ſend you Mellons?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ripen'd Hopes?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Apricocks, Figges?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Vegetable Embraces.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And ſmooth Epiſtles? Go you vile abuſers
Of what you cannot compaſs; 'cauſe you nouriſh
Deſires, you will diſcharge the ſin on us.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Ladies you're much deceiv'd: had you the Aphoriſmes
Of th'Art perfect, that each word ſhould go
With a deſigne, that not an Eye ſhould be
Lift up, or caſt down without myſtery—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Could you force ſighs, faigne paſſions, manage looks,
Seaſon your jeſts, ſpeak with a Manner ſtill—

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Should you conſult a Decade of Chambermaids,
And ſadly adviſe with your Chryſtall Oracles,
In which Attire your Beauties would appear
Moſt ſtrong; in what contrivance your ſweet Graces
Would be moſt fierce, and overcome Spectators,
You ſhould not have one look to quench the fire.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: You ſhall be Veſtals by compulſion ſtill—

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: You ſhall make Verſes to me e're I've done;
Call me your Caelius, your Corinnus, and
Make me the Man o'th' Book inſome Romance,
And after all I will not yield.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You're got
Into a ſafe field of Diſcourſe, where you
〈◊〉 ſure, that Modeſtie will not ſuffer us
To anſwer you in a direct line.

sp.speaker: Coſm.
sp.l: You were
Wont to go whining up and down, and make
Diſmall Soliloquies in ſhady Woods—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Diſcourſe with Trees—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And Dialogue with Eccho's—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Send Meſsages by Birds, make diſcreet Thruſhes
Your truſty Agents 'twixt your Loves and you—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Which Loves you call'd Nymphs—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: When indeed they were
Milkmaids, or ſome ſuch Drudges. This your rating
And prizing of your ſelves, and ſtanding off,
Comes not from any bett'ring of your Judgements,
But from your Mouth's being out of taſte.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Pray y' what
Employment are you fit for?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Ile aſſure you
None about you.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Their whole Employment is
To goe Embaſſadors 'twixt retir'd Ladies—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: To ask how this great Ladies Phyſick wrought—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Give an account o'th' vertue of her Drugs.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Make perfect Audit of the Tale of ſighs
Some little Dog did breath in his firſt ſleep:
Goe you Reproach and Refuſe of your Countrey.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: You ſpeak moſt valiantly Heroick Lady.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Pray Venus you permit the Lords to rule
The Common-wealth again, when they come home

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Know Sir, they ſhall not—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And you ſhall conſent,
Ayd, and aſſiſt us in't in ſpight of you,
Willing or •• willing, all's one.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Wee'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Your Company grows dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: 'Tis half Treaſon
To hear you talk.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Before you 'tis very ſafe.
You'll never dare t' engage your ſelves ſo much
I' th' Army, as to inform the King of't.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Come,
Let us away too.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: We will vex 'em through
All ſorts of Torment, meet 'em at each Corner,
Write Satyrs, and make Libels of 'em, put 'em
In Shows, & Mock-Shows, Maſques, & Plaies, preſent 'em
In all Dramatique Poetry: they ſhall
Be ſung i'th Markets, wee'll not let 'em reſt
'Till themſelves ſue to be o'th' Female Covenant.

sp.speaker: Pan,
sp.l: BUt hold, here comes Eumela.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Lady Secretary
Unto our future State, God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: You beſtow Offices, as City Mothers
After their Travail, do give Flowers between
Their Houſe and Juno's Temple, to the next
They meet, or as you do your Ribbands, to
Entangle, not Reward.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Then you are Wiſe
And Politique ſtill—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Of the Male-faction Lady?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And you will ſuffer by Preſcription ſtill?
But to be ſerious now; what do you do?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: That which you would, if you ſhould come to Rule:
Wake, Sleep, Riſe, Dreſs, Eat, Viſit, and Converſe,
And let the State alone.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Y'are very ſhort.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Indeed I am ſome what now in haſte; I'm going
To meet a pair of Ladies, that would willing
Keep their own Sex, and not turn Lords.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You mean

sp.speaker: Florina,
sp.l: and Malthora, thoſe that are
Sad now, that one day they may be in Hiſtory
Under the name of Turtles.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: What Dialect may
Thoſe Ladies grieve in? Dorick or Ionick?
Doe they make Verſes yet?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Their Manners are
A kind of Satyr upon yours; though they
Intend it not, the people read 'em ſo.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: 'Cauſe they have laid aſide their Jewels, and ſo
Blinded their Garments—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: 'Cauſe they eat their ſweet-meats
In a black Cloſet, they are counted faithfull,
The ſole Penelope's o'th' time, the Ladies
Of the chaſte Web i'th' abſence of their Lords.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Your ſadneſſe would be ſuch perhaps, if you
Would take the pains to ſhew the Art of Mourning.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Is there another way of grieving then?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: This is not grief, but ſtands to be thought grief:
They are not of ſuch vaunting popular ſorrow;
Their Tapers are not dy'd in diſmall hue,
Aud ſet in Ebon Candleſticks; they wear
No ſad black Sarcenet Smocks, nor do they ſmutch
Their women, to be ſerv'd by mourning Faces;
This were to grieve to Oſtentation,
Not ro a reall friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is there friendſhip
Think you 'twixt man and wife?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: You'll ſay, perhaps,
You, and your Husband, have not been friends yet.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Madam, you prophecy.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I might be thought t'have done ſo,
Had I foretold a truth to come, but this
Is Hiſtory already.

sp.speaker: Coſ,
sp.l: If they do not this,
Nor wear the day out in a hood winkt 100m,
Where there's no living thing beſides the Clock,
Nor yet take Phyſick to look pale, what doe they?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: They grieve themſelves, their Doctor grieves not for them:
They do that in the Abſence of their Lords
That you would in the Preſence of your own.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: You ſee we look as fat, and fair as ever—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Your Kitchin's warm, your Box, and Pencils fail not.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: —VVe are as long in dreſſing as before—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: And have the ſame Romancys read, the ſame
Letters brought to you, whilſt y'are doing it.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: —Sleep, and take reſt, as then, and altogether
Speak as much wit as we did before the wars.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: And to as little purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Fie Eumela!
That you ſhould be ſo obſtinate, as to hear
VVealth, Honour, Pleaſure, Rule, and every good
Knock at your door, and yet not let 'em in.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Madam, I know my Looking-glaſſe wo'n't ſhew
The altering o'th' State, when it preſents
The changes of my Face, and that I cannot
Order the Kingdome, as I do my Hair.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yonder's your buſineſs; Madam, there are three
Sad things arriv'd, two Ladies and a Lute.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: But ſhall I write you down before you go
The thirteenth in the Rowl of the Aſſerters
Of Female Liberty?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: If Liberty be the thing
You ſo much ſtand for, pray you give me mine;
I neither grant, nor yet deny; I will
Conſider.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: VVe diſmiſs you, Madam, then
Unto your ſerious Counſell.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Fare you well.

div.head: ACT I. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Eumela goes to Florina and Malthora who are ſate in the Grove.

sp.speaker: Elo.
sp.l: OCome, Eumela, thou doſt know, without thee
Our thoughts are Deſarts, Rocks, and Sands, and all
That either Nature's abſent from, or hath
Reſerv'd unto her ſelf alone.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I bring you
Noiſe, Trouble, Tumult, and the World; but if
There were that power in my worthleſs preſence,
That I could caſt a day upon your thoughts,
You ſhould not think of Places that are ſacred
To Night, and Silence: Viſits ſtill, and Feaſts
And the whole Ring and Throng of Mirth ſhould ſtir
In your delighted Souls.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Prethee Eumela
Is there no ſecret ancient Grove, that hath
Stood from the birth of Nature to this time,
Whoſe vaſt, high, hollow Trees ſeem each a Temple,
Whoſe paths no curious Eye hath yet found out,
Free from the Foot and Axe.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: If I could tell you
It were found out already.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Haſt thou read
Of any Mountain, whoſe cold frozen top
Sees Hail i'th' Bed, not yet grown round, and Snow
I'th' Fleece, not Carded yet, whoſe hanging weight
Archeth ſome ſtill deep River, that for fear
Steals by the foot of't without noiſe.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Alas!
Theſe are the things, that ſome poor wretched Lover
Unpittied by his ſcornfull Shepherdeſſe
Would wiſh for, after that he had look'd up
Unto the Heavens, and call'd her Cruell thrice,
And vow'd to dye.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I prethee pardon me;
I live without my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: But I have read
Of a tall ſecret Grove, where loving Winds
Breathing their ſighs among the trembling Boughs,
Blow Odes, and Epods; where a murmuring Brook
Will let us ſee the Brother to our Sun,
And ſhew's another World there under water.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Prethee let's go, and find it out, and live there.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Our Ancient Poet Linus ſomewhere ſings
Of ſome ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thou alwaies doſt deceive us;
Thou told'ſt us of an Eccho too, and when
Thou brought'ſt us to it, thou had'ſt put Philaenis
Behind the Wall, to give us all the Anſwers.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Yes, and thy bringing in my Father's Dwarf
With Bow and Wings, and Quiver at his back,
Inſtead of Cupid, to conveigh us Letters
Through th' Air from hence to Crete, was but a trick
To put away our ſadneſs. But I had
Almoſt forgot what we came for, I prethee
Take up the Lute there, and let's hear the Ode;
That thou did'ſt promiſe us; I hope 'tis ſad.

l.hi: TO carve our Loves in Myrtle rinds,
And tell our Secrets to the Woods,
To ſen̄d our Sighs by faithful Winds,
And truſt our Tears unto the Flouds,
To call where no man hears,
And think that Rocks have Ears▪
To Walke, and Reſt, to Live, and Dye,
And yet not know Whence, How, or Why;
To have our Hopes with Fears ſtill checkt,
To credit Doubts, and Truth ſuſpect,
This, this is that we may
A Lover's Abſence ſay.
Follies without, are Cares within;
Where Eyes do fail, there Souls begin.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thou art a harmleſs Syren fair Eumela.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis very true indeed; thou feed'ſt at once,
And doſt correct our follyes: but wert thou
As we, thoud'ſt do the like.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: For Love's ſake tell me
VVhy ſhould you ſeek out Groves, where the bright Sun
Can make no day, although he throw upon 'em
VVhole flouds of Light, Places where Nature will
Be blind in ſpight of Him? VVhy ſhould you fancy
Caves fit to write ſad Revelations in?
Or why a Lover ſtretcht on ſhaggy Moſs
Between two Beds of Poppey to procure
One Minut's ſlumber?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Theſe, Eumela, are not
The Journyes but Digreſſions of our Souls,
That being once inform'd with Love, muſt work,
And rather wander, than ſtand ſtill. I know
There is a VViſdom to be ſhewn in Paſſions;
And there are ſtayd and ſetled griefs: I'l be
Severe unto my ſelf, and make my Soul
Seek out a Regular Motion, towards him
VVhom it moves to, and thou ſhalt ſhortly ſee
Love bleed, and yet ſtoop to Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: MAdam I muſt away; Olyndus yonder
Is haſting towards me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Farwell Eumela,
Be ever happy.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: And may ſome good God
Cheriſh thy Loves, as thou doſt cheriſh others. Ex. Fl & M • .

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: My Lord Olyndus, what's your bus'neſs to me?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Vertuous Eumela, you muſt doe me the favour
To give this Letter into th' Princeſs's hands
With all the ſpeed and ſecrecy you may.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I carry with me Night, and wings my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O my Olyndus, were there not that thing
That we call Friend, Earth would one Deſart be,
And Men Alone ſtill, though in Company.

div.head: ACT. II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Macheſſa, Philaenis, and after a while Coſmeta, Pandena, Rhodia.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: GIve me my Javelin; hangs my Fauchion right?
Three Ladys ſayſt thou? So! go fetch 'em in now.
What? goes the Tilting on I mention'd? Is there
No Juſt, nor Turnament yet granted out?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: You're well appointed Madam.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: How I hate
That Name of Madam, it befits a Chamber:
Give me the words o'th' Field, ſuch as you'd give
To fairer Ladyes pricking o'r the Plains
On foaming Steeds. But I do pardon you.
Shews not this Scarf and Fauchion far more comely,
Than paultry pyebald Ribbands, and young Bodkins?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You wear a rigid Beauty, fierce Delights.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Your Pleaſures threaten, and your ſtubborn Graces
Tempt, and defend at once.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Why now y' are right.
And what ſay'ſt thou, my little Noon-tide ſhadow?
My truſty Pigmy?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now indeed, and truly—

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Hell o' theſe ſimpring Proteſtations!
Thou ſinfull Inch of ſhort Mortality,
Give Ear to my Inſtructions: here I ſwear
By th' Sacred Order of my Lady-Errantry,
If thou effeminat'ſt thy diſcourſe once more
With theſe preciſe, minc'd, Little▪Siſters-Vows,
Thy breath is forfeit.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: By that bloudy Fauchion—

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: I there's a Wench, ſpit from the mouth of Mavors
Bellona was thy Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: —And that fierce Javelin,
I'd rather ſee a Plume o'rſhade your back
With a large, generous Careleſneſs; than a bunch
Of fidling Feathers hang before you, juſt
As modeſt fig-leaves do in naked Pictures.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Thou little 'Vantage of Mankind, thou Grain
That Nature put into the Scales to make
Weight to the VVorld, thou tak'ſt me very much.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The Sable Fan, which you wore laſt upon
Your white Lawn-Apron, made you ſhew juſt like
The Ace of Clubs, with a black ſpot i'th' middle.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: VVhy how now little Miſchief? is't not knaviſh
And waggiſh, like a very Page o'th' Court?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: VVhat uſe do you mean her for?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Have you not read?
To ſummon Knights from th'tops of Caſtle wals.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I fancy thoſe brave Scythian Heroines;
Thoſe Noble, valiant Amazons like you.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Nature did ſhew them only as my Types.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: There's nothing wanting but adventures: We
Shall quickly now requite the Errant Knights
That help diſtreſſed Ladies to their wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: I'l diſobliege our Sex. If that you find
Any imprison'd, or inchanted
Tell him Macheſſa's his deliverance.
Said I Macheſſa? Hold! that word Macheſſa
Sailes through my Lips with too ſmall breath. I'l have
A Name that Mouths ſhall travell with: let's ſee?
Wee'l put a Prologue to it: So! I have it;
It is concluded—Monſter-quelling-Woman-

l.hi: Obliging-Man-delivering-Macheſſa,

sp.l: She, She is his deliverance: tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do ſhe that can; I would you'd change your Name;
'Tis longer than your Self, and if it were
Some three foot ſhorter, 'twere as high as I am.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: See who 'tis knocks; you do not know your Office;
Bellona, hear my Name, and ſend Adventures.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: THe Courtiers Madam; work for us! remember.
Pray ſtand aſide as ſoon as we begin.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Save you Macheſſa.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: I've a Name beſides,
By which I mean Poſterity ſhall know me;
The word is grown: 'tis Monſter-quelling-Woman-

l.hi: Obliging-Man-delivering-Macheſſa.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Sweet Monſter-quelling-Woman-ob-and ſo forth-
Wee've brought a buſineſs to you.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Valiant Captain,
What is th' Affront that's moſt in faſhion now?

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: why doe you ask me Lady?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Cauſe y'are wont
To receive moſt, and ſo can tell the neweſt;
VVhich now perhaps you come to have redreſt.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: VVhat is the ſtrength o'th' Subject think you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Why what know I?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Who ſhould Sir, if not you
That have ſo oft been beaten by all ſorts,
And all degrees of men?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Which Lady now
Sends you moſt Favours?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: VVhich moſt Mellons?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Which
Moſt Gums, and Spikenard Boxes?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Who preſents you
With the beſt Figs?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The plumpeſt Bulbi?

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: You,
And you, and you; you will not worry me?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: By your Periwig, Captain, but we will.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: By your
Falſe Teeth we will.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And your glaſſe-Eye we will.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: For Jove's ſake, Madam.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: S'heart I'm not breath-proof.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Alas, we han't begun yet.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Let's beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: We will not be beſeech'd.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Think upon Reſt,
As a paſt pleaſure of your youth—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You ſhall not
Be idle quietly in the Preſence Chamber.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You ſhan't tell lies in quiet to the Waiters.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Nor, when you've done, ſhare in their meat in quiet.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Wee'l meet you at the Bath—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: You ſhall not waſh
Without diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: At the Theater too—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You ſhall not miſconceive good Comedies
Without vexation—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And at Flora's Park.—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You ſhall not cheat at little Horſe-races
Without diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: In th' Temple then—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: You ſhall not kneel in quiet at the Altars—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Wee'l hearken, and obſerve—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You ſhall not have
So much free time, as to appoint a meeting
With her kneels next y'—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: If that y'are bid to Supper—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Wee'l ſtay you, though y'have got a warrant to
Ride poſt to eat.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Good Madam, be content.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And if y'are ſet—

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Hell, and Furies—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: You
Shall riſe, and prove perfidious to the hot
Cramm'd Fowl upon your trencher.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Wee'l ſubſcribe—
Are you content?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And when y'are weary of
All this—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Wee'l doe all this again.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Wee'l keep you,
As they doe Hawkes—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Watching untill you leave
Your wildneſs, and prove inward.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Hear y'Madam—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: We will ſubſcribe.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Come quickly then, leſt that
sp.stage: Mach. ſteps in and draws till they all paſs out.
sp.l: We take a toy, and will not let you.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Stay.
The Gods have deſtin'd this ſhould be the firſt
Of my Adventures—go—y'are free.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: Our thanks
Will be too ſmall a Recompence.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: The Deed
Will pay it ſelf; Vertue's not Mercenary:
Or, if it be, mine is not. So; I do
Begin to come in Action now. To do
And ſuffer, doth engroſs whole Nature, and
I will engroſs both them; I'l ſet all free,
But only Glory; her I'l Captive lead,
Making her Trumpet only ſound my Name,
That is, the Sexe's. I am all their Fame.
How goes your Bus'neſs on?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Vertue and Fortune
Joyn in it both.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Eumela is come over,
Hath undertook the Machin, and hath promis'd
To bring it to that paſs, that neither Queen,
Nor Princeſs ſhall gainſay't. Florina, and
Malthora both have given in their Reaſons,
Which I have anſwer'd, and convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: If that
It come to any danger, let me know it.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Eumela welcome; does your bus'neſs thrive?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Too faſt.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: What? have you ſent to th' Ports?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: All's ſafe.
Macheſſa's ours you ſay—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes, and Philandra.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Cleora and Earina buſie Sticklers,
Oenone and Hermione ſent as Emiſſaries
To try the farther Cities—Paria hath
A pretty ſtroke among the Privy Chamber.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: You've loſt no time.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Nor will, Coſmeta—
Pſecas, and Dorcas, Cloe, and Plecuſa,
Phillis, and Glauca, ſwore this morning all
As I was dreſſing.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: On what Book I pray?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: On the Greek Epigtams, Madam, or Anacreon,
I know not which: they bind alike.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: What hopes
Have we o'th' Women of Lapythia?
How ſtand the Dames of Salamin affected?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Why Lycas ſent to give them a fair Largeſs
Of Loaves and Wine, & then, whiles that well cheers 'em,
Eugenia brings 'em a moſt promiſing Anſwer
From ſome corrupted Oracle, and ſo leads
The ſuperſtitious Souls to what ſhe pleaſeth.
This is a ground, a thing ſuppos'd. The Plot
Is wholly now upon Florina, there
It knits, and gathers, breaks, and joyns again;
She's Wiſe, and Noble—we muſt find a way
Not thought on yet to gain her.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But the Queen
And Princeſs—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: They perceive the buſineſs ripens,
That it doth move the limbs, and can for need
Shift, and defend it ſelf, and therfore doe
By me make promiſe of a generall meeting
As ſoon as may be: i'th' mean time, we have
Full leave to gather any Contributions,
Gold, Silver, Jewels, Garments, any thing
Conducing to maintain the Publique Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Goddeſs Eumela!

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Goe, fall off, the Princeſs
Is at hand—I'lgoe mingle Counſels.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Eumela you are come moſt opportunely.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: This to your Highneſs from my L. Olyndus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You're happy that your Love is with you ſtill,
That you can ſee, and hear, and ſpeak to him.
Venus doth favour you more than the whole
Kingdome Eumela; Mars for her ſake's kind to you.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs it happy: but Olyndus
Cannot be brought to think it ſo; he fears
His ſickneſs will by ſome be conſtru'd Love;
Which, if his Valour in his Country's danger
Durſt give the upper hand, ev'n at the Altar,
Though Venus did her ſelf look on, hee'd pull
Out of his Breaſt, and caſt aſide, as ſome
Unhallow'd part o'th' Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: His King
Hath found him truly valiant. E'r I open
This Paper, you muſt ſtate one Point, Eumela,
Suppoſe me buſie in the holy Rites
Of our adored Venus: if by chance
I caſt mine Eye upon ſome Princely viſage,
And feel a Paſſion, is the Goddeſs wrong'd?
Or the Religion leſſe?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Our Loves what are they
But howerly Sacrifices, only wanting
The preaſe and tumult of Solemnity?
If then i'th' heat and Achme of Devotion
We drink a new fiame in, can it be ought
But to increaſe the Worſhip? and what Goddeſs
Was ever angry that the holy Prieſt
Increas'd her Fires, and made 'em burn more clear?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: True, but ſuppoſe the Face then ſeen doth never
Appear more after, is not that a ſign
The Goddeſs is diſpleas'd?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: That it a while
Appears not, is to cheriſh, not extinguiſh
The Paſſion thence conceiv'd: as Perſecutions
Make Piety ſtronger ſtill, and bring th' Afflicted
Unto the glory of renowned Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is there then no hope but that? Alas!
This man perhaps might periſh in ſome War
As now (But O ye Gods avert the Fate!)
And then th' unhappy ſighing Virgin fall
From that her feigned Heaven.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: It cannot be;
Venus deſtroyes her Deity, if she ſhew
And then delude: she will not loſe what once
S • ' hath made her own; She that knits hearts by th' Eyes,
Will keep the knot faſt by their Entercourſe;
If you have once but ſeen, and lov'd, permit
The reſt unto the Deity. Will it pleaſe
Your Highneſs to peruſe the Letter? 'tis
Of moment I preſume: why bluſh you Madam?
And, while I ask you, why look pale?

sp.speaker: Luc.

l.hi: Eumela,

sp.l: The ſuppoſition's truth; lately, thou knoweſt,
I did aſſiſt at Venus Sacrifice;
He, whom I ſaw, and lov'd, ſaw, and lov'd too,
And now hath writ—but let Olyndus tell him
I will not ſee him, though he were the Soul
Of all Mankind.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hear me—yet if
He have a true undoubted Friend, he may
send him, I'l meet him in the Myrtle Grove,
And tell him more.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I will obey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But ſtay—
And yet that's all.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Soul doth give
Brightneſs to th' Eye, and ſome ſay, That the Sun,
If not enlight'ned by th' Intelligence
That doth inhabit it, would ſhine no more
Than a dull Clod of Earth: ſo Love, that is
Brighter than Eye, or Sun, if not enlight'ned
By Reaſon, would ſo much of Luſtre loſe
As to become but groſs, and foul Deſire;
I muſt refine his Paſſion; None can wooe
Nobly, but he that hath done Nobly too.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: YOur Highneſs here alone?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But ſo long only
As gives you leave to ask. What? ſad Florina?
I'd thought your Soul had dwelt within it ſelf,
Been ſingle a full preſence, and that you
Had ſet your ſelf up your own Trophy now
Full of true Joy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Tis hard to caſt off that
That we call Paſſion, we may veyl, and cloud it,
But't will break out at laſt. True Joy is that
Which now I cannot have.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How ſo Florina?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: True Joy conſiſts in Looks, and Words, and Letters,
Which now an Abſence, equall to Divorce,
Hath wholly barr'd us of.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Looks, Words, and Letters!
Alas they are but only ſo much Air
Diverſly form'd, & ſo the food of that
Changeable Creature; not the Viands of
True conſtant Lovers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But, if I ſee not,
Is not my Joy grown leſs, who could not love
'Till I firſt ſaw? and if I hear not, can
I have the perfect Harmony of pleaſure,
Who ſomething ow to words that I firſt yeelded?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who ever yet was won by words? we come
Conquer'd, and when we grant, we do not yeeld,
But do confeſs that we did yeeld before.
But be thoſe Senſes ſome Contentments, Madam,
You muſt not yet make them the great, and true
Eſſentiall Joy that only can conſiſt
In the bright perfect Union of two Spirits.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But ſeeing thoſe Spirits cannot work, but by
The Organs of the Body, 'tis requir'd
That (to the full perfection of this Joy)
Bodies ſhould be near-Neighbours too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I muſt
Confeſs that I ſubſcribe unto the Princeſs,
And ſomwhat too to you: the Preſence may
Conveigh, and fill, and poliſh Joy; but yet
To ſee, or hear, cannot be Joyes themſelves.
And where this Preſence is deny'd, the Soul
Makes uſe of higher, and more ſubtle means,
And by the ſtrength of thought creates a Preſence
Where there is none.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Alas! how we doe loſe
Our ſelves in ſpeculation of our Loves,
As if they were unbody'd Eſſences!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would
Eumela now were here; Shee'd tell us, All
Is the ſame Joy, as Love from ſight, or thought,
Is the ſame Love; and that Love's turning to
Either of them, is only but a Needle
Turning to ſeverall points, no diverſe flame,
But only divers degrees of the ſelf-ſame.
Come Madam let's away and ſeek her out.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: NOt ſee me, ſay you, though I were the Soul
Of all Mankind?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: They were the words return'd—
But if he have a true undoubted friend,
• nd him, I'l tell him more.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Have I deſerted
• y Country, now in danger, where I had
• ook Honour Captive, and for ever fixt her
• s an Intelligence unto my Sword,
• o move and guide it? have I ſcorn'd my Fortunes,
• nd laid aſide the Prince? have I contemn'd
• hat much priz'd thing call'd Life, and wreſtled with
• oth Winds and Flouds, through which I have arriv'd
• ither at laſt? and all this not to ſee her?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Doth ſhe betray, or undiſguiſe you to
• he State? Doth ſhe forbid you, Sir, to love?
• ffection is not wanting, where 'tis wiſe;
• he only doth forbid you that you ſee her.

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: Only forbid me to be happy, only
• orbids me to enjoy my ſelf; What could
• he more, were I her Enemy? Olyndus
• aſt thou at no time told her, that there was

•
Cretan call'd thee Friend?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Perhaps Sh' hath found this way to ſend for thee.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.l: Though I have thought it worth the boaſting, that
• hariſtus is my friend, yet by that Word,
• acred to Noble Souls, I never had
• o much acceſs to tell her any thing,
Much leſs my Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt go Olyndus.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: When my eyes ſee her, yours do; when I talk,
Tis you that talk; we are true friends, and one,
• ay that one interchang'd; for I am you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis true thou art my friend, ſo much my friend,
That my ſelf am not more my ſelf, than thou art:
• f thou doſt go, I go—But ſtay—Didſt not
• hou ſay mine eyes were thine? thou didſt: if that
• e ſo, then thou muſt love her too, and then—
Olyndus thou muſt ſtay.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: She loves you ſo,
(As my Eumela doth inform me) that
No humane Image can deface the Print
That you have drawn i'th' Tablet of her Soul.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If that ſhe loves me ſo, why then ſhe muſt
Love thee ſo too; for thou and I are one.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Why then, Sir, if you go your ſelf, the iſſue
Will be the ſame however, ſo, when ſhe
Loves you Shee'l love me too.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: We are both one
In hearts and minds Olyndus: but thoſe Minds
Are cloath'd with Bodies. Bodies that do oft—
I know not what—yet thou haſt an Eumela,
A fair Eumela truſt me—Thou muſt go—
But uſe not any Language, Geſture, Looks,
That may be conſtru'd ought above Reſpect;
For thou art young and Beautifull, and Valiant,
And all that Ladies long for.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: When I prove
So treacherous to my Friend, my ſelf, my fair
Eumela, mark me with that hatefull brand
That Ignominy hath not diſcover'd yet,
But doth reſerve to ſear the fouleſt Monſter
That ſhall appear in Nature.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I beleeve thee:
Yet ſomething bids me ſtill not let thee go.
But I'l not hearken to it; though my Soul
Should tell me 'twere not fit, I'd not beleeve
My Soul could think ſo.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: How reſolve you then?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt. I do beleeve—and yet
I do—I know not what—O my Lucaſia!
O my Olyndus! divers waies I bend,
Divided 'twixt the Lover, and the Friend.

div.head: ACT. III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Olyndus to Lucaſia in the Grove.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: MMay't pleaſe your Highneſs, Madam—
I have a friend ſo much my ſelf, that I
Cann't ſay he's abſent now, yet he hath ſent me
To be here preſent for him: we enterchange
Boſoms, and Counſels, Thoughts, and Souls ſo much,
That he entreats you to conceive you ſpake
To him in me; All that you ſhall depoſite
Will be in ſafe, and faithfull Ears; the ſame
Truſt you expect from him, ſhall keep your words,
And the ſame Night conceal 'em: 'tis Chariſtus
The noble Cretan.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: When you ſaid your Friend,
The reſt was needleſs; I conceive him all
That makes up Vertue, all that we call Good
Whom you Olyndus give your Soul to; yet
I'd rather court his Valour, than his Love,
Did he ſhine bright in Armour, call for Dangers,
Eager to cut his way through ſtubborn Troops,
Ev'n this my ſoftneſs, arm'd as he, could follow
And prompt his Arm, ſupply him with freſh Fury,
And dictate higher dangers. Then when Duſt
And Bloud hath ſmear'd him (a diſguiſe more worthy
Of Princes far, than that he wears) I could
Embrace him freſh from Conqueſt, and conceive him
As fair as ever any yet appear'd
To longing Virgins in their Amorous Dreams.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Fury could never from the Den of danger
Awake that horror yet, that bold Chariſtus
Durſt not attempt, ſtand equall with, and then
Conquer, and trample, and contemn.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Revenge
And Hate I do confeſs, may ſometimes carry
The Soul beyond it ſelf to do, and ſuffer:
But the things then are Furious, not Great,
And ſign the Actor Headlong, but not Vertuous.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: He that can do this, Madam, and Love too,
Muſt needs be vertuous; that holy Flame
Clean and untainted, as the freſh deſires
Of Infant Saints, enters not Souls that are
Of any foul Complexion. He that Loves,
Even in that he Loves, is good: and as
He is no leſs an Atheiſt, that denies
The Gods to be moſt happy, than the Man
That dares Affirm there are no Gods at all;
So he's no leſs an Heretick, that ſhall
Deny Love to be Vertuous, than he
That dares Affirm there is no Love at all.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But he hath left his Country now, when that
Her Wealth, her Name, her Temples, and her Altars,
Her Gods, and Liberty, ſtand yet upon
Th'uncertain Dye; when Danger cals his Arm,
And Glory ſhould arreſt his Spirit there;
And this to Court one, whom he knows not, whether
She may think Vertue a meer Airy word,
And Honour but a blaſt, invented to
Make catching Spirits dare, and do high things.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: That you are Vertuous, is a knowledge, that
All muſt confeſs they have, but only thoſe
That have not Eyes: For if that Souls frame Bodies,
And that the Excellence of the Architect
Appear in the perfection of the Structure,
Whether you have a Soul enrich'd with vertues,
Muſt be a blind Man's doubt: Nature dares not
Thruſt out ſo much deceit into the World;
'Twould make us not beleeve her works were meant
For true firm Peeces, but Deluſions only.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Though I muſt not agree t' you, to paſs by
What you have ſaid, If I were Vertuous,
You muſt confeſs him ſo far ignorant yet,
As not to know whether I'd Love, or no.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.l: This Knowledge is of more Extent than th' other.
For being that to be lov'd is the Effect
Of your own worths, you muſt love all mens Loves
As a Confeſſion of your Graces, that
Your ſelves have drawn from them. That which your Beauty
Produceth, is a Birth as dear unto you,
As are your Children.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Should there more than one
Love us (if this hold) we muſt love them too,
And ſo that Sacred Tye that joyns the Soul
To one, and but to one, were but a Fable,
A thing in Poetry, not in the Creature.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: One is your Trophy: and he Lov'd as That
The Reſt but Witneſſes: thus Princes, when
They Conquer Princes, though they only count
Thoſe Names of Glory, and Renown, their Victory,
Take yet their meaner Subjects in, as fair
Acceſſes to their Triumphs, who, although
They are not the main Prize, are ſome what yet
That doth confirm that there was worth, and force,
To which the Main did juſtly yeeld.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Be't then
That I do love his Love, I am not yet
Bound to accept it in what ſhape ſoever
It doth appear; the Manner, Time, and Place
May not be reliſh'd, though the thing be lik'd.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: For theſe he doth expect your Dictates, with
As much Religion, as he would the Anſwers
Of Sacred Oracles, and with the ſame
Vow of Performance.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You muſt tell him then.
He muſt go back, and there do Honorably;
Succour his Country, cheer the Souldier, fight,
Spend, and disburſe the Prince, where e'r he goes,
Get him a Name, and Title upon Cyprus.
I will not ſee him 'till he hath Conquer'd, till
He hath rid high in Triumph, and when this
Is done, let him conſider then, it is
My Father, & my Subjects, and my Kingdom
That he hath Conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: I am an Agent only,
And therefore muſt be faithful.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But withall
To ſhew that I reject him not, you may
Tell him, that being he hath ſuch a friend,
Whiles he is abſent I will love Olyndus
Inſtead of him.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: But that my Friend is in me
I ſhould have deem'd it Sacrilege, to have had
A thought like that ſuggeſted. My Chariſtus,
Were he not ſomething carefull in his Love,
(I will not call him Jealous) were beyond
The Lot of Man: I muſt not tell him all,
Some may be hid; yet how ſhall I unriddle
The Myſtery of this Anſwer? But the knots
That Love doth tye, himſelf will only find
The way to looſe—

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. II.
div.l: Souls once poſſeſſ'd, as his, are moſt impatient,
They meet what they ſhould ſtay for.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Dear Olyndus,
Pardon that I expect not, but make haſt
To intercept my Doom Others perhaps
May wait the punctuall Minute, and obſerve
The juſt and even Period: but Chariſtus
Doth love too ſlow, when time, and Sun can bind him
Unto a regular Motion.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Would you had
Been there your ſelf! would you had drunk in all
The Looks, Words, Graces, and Divinities
That I have done! I'm like the Prieſt that's full
Of his inſpiring God, and am poſſeſs'd
With ſo much rapture, that methinks I could
Bear up my ſelf without a Wing, or Chariot,
And hoverc'r the Earth, ſtill dropping ſomething
That ſhould take root in Kingdoms, and come up
The Good of people.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Let me ask thee then
As we do thoſe that do come freſh from Viſions,
What ſaw'ſt thou there?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: That which I ſee ſtill, that
Which will not out; I ſaw a Face that did
Seem to participate of Flames, and Flowers;
Eyes in which Light combin'd with Jet to make
Whiteneſs be thought the Blot, and Black hereafter
Purchaſe the Name of Innocence, and Luſtre.
The whole was but one ſolid Light, and had I
Not ſeen our Goddeſs riſing from the Flouds
Pourtray'd leſs fair, leſs Goddeſs, I had thought
The thing I ſaw, and talk'd with, muſt have been
The Tutelar Deity of this our Iſland.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: That I ſhould let thee go! that I ſhould be
So impious to my ſelf, as not to break
Her great Commands, and ſo become a Martyr
By daring to be happy 'gainſt her will—
But on Olyndus.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: You may think this
The Height, the Acme, and the All of her:
But when I tell you, that She hath a Mind
That hides all this, and makes it not appear,
Diſparaging as 'twere, what ever may
Be ſeen without her, then you'l thus exclame;
Nature, thou wert o'rſeen to put ſo mean
A Frontiſpeece to ſuch a Building.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Give me,
O quickly give me the whole Miracle,
Or preſently I am not.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Think, Chariſtus,
Think out the reſt, as 'tis, I cannot ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Alas! what ſhould I think?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Conceive a Fire
Simple and thin; to which that Light we ſee,
And ſee by, is ſo far impure, that 'tis
Only the ſtain, and blemiſh of the World;
And if it could be plac'd with it in one
And the ſame Tablet, would but only ſerve
As bound and ſhadow to it: Then conceive
A Subſtance that the Gods have ſet apart,
And when they would put generous Motions
Into a Mortall Breaſt, do take the Soul
And couch it there, ſo that what e'r we call
Vertue in us, is only but a Turning
And Inclination toward her from whom
This Pow'r was firſt deriv'd.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: What preſent God
Lent thee his Eyes, and ſtood blind by, whiles thou
Did'ſt gaze, and ſurfet on theſe Glories?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Others
Do Love the ſhape, the Geſture, and the Man,
But She the Vertue. Mark Chariſtus. She
Saies She could Court you ring'd about with Dangers,
Doat on you ſmear'd, and ſtiff with hoftile Bloud,
Count and exact your wounds, as a due ſum
You are to pay to Valour; All which when
I told her was in Love, ſhe ſaid I did
Preſent a ſpark, when ſhe deſir'd a full
And glorious Conſtellation—to be ſhort,
She ſaies you muſt go back, do honourably,
Get you a Name upon the Cyprian Forces;
And bids when you have done all this, conſider
It is her Father, and his Subjects, and
His Kingdome that you conquer—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: And her ſelf
That I ſhall loſe by doing ſo. If I
Return, and Crete be Conquer'd, then She will
Count me Spoyl, and Luggage; and my Love
Only a Slave's Affection. If I Conquer,
And Cyprus follow my Triumphant Chariot,
My Love wil then be Tyranny: and She,
How can ſhe light an Hymeneal Torch
From her lov'd Countries Flame? I am rejected,
Chariſtus is a Name of ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: VVhat Fates
Dare throw that Name upon my Friend? To ſhew
That ſhe rejects you not, becauſe there is
That Truſt, rhat Faith, and that Confuſion of
Chariſtus and Olyndus 'twixt us, in the mean
VVhiles he is abſent, tell him, ſaith ſhe, that
I'll love Olyndus in his ſtead.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: How! Man
Th' haſt dealt diſhonourably. This the Light?
And this the Fire that makes that Light a ſtain?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: This I foretold my ſelfe: my good Chariſtus
Let not your Anger carry you beyond
The bent of Reaſon; can I give account
Of others Paſſions? did I firſt conceive
The words my ſelf; then ſpeak'em?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O ye Gods!
Where is the Faith? where the Olyndus now?
Th' haſt been a Factor for thy ſelf: I'd thought
I'd ſent a Friend, but he's return'd a Merchant,
And will divide the Wealth.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Far be that Brand
From your Olyndus! far from your Lucaſia!
She hath a Face hath ſo much Heaven in it,
And this Olyndus ſo much Worſhip of it,
That he muſt firſt put on another Shape,
And become Monſter, e'r he dare but look
Upon her with a thought that's Masculine.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Peace Treachery! I am too cold; my Anger
Is dull and lazy yet. I'l ſearch that Breaſt,
Aud dig out falſhood from the ſecret'ſt Corner
In all thy Heart, here, in the very place
That thou haſt wrong'd me.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: There is nothing here
That my Charistus knows not. 'Pray you open,
And ſearch, and judge; and when you find all true,
Say you deſtroy'd a Friend.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: It is your Art
I ſee to wooe, but I will make you ſpeak
Something that is not Flattery.

sp.speaker: Olyn.

l.hi: Olyndus

sp.l: Ne'r lov'd the Man as friend yet, whom he did
Feat as an Enemy. 'I is one part of Valour
That I durſt now receive, conceal, and help you,
Here in the Boſome of that State, which hath
Caſt out a ſpear into the Cretan Field,
And bid you War.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thou haſt already here
Betray'd my Love; thy falſhood will proceed
Unto my Perſon next. I'd thought I'd been
Claſp'd in Embraces, but I find I am
Entangled in a Net.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Y'are ſafe as in
The Boſome of your Father, take this Veyl
Of Paſſion from your Eyes; and you'l behold
The ſame Olyndus ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: The ſame Deceiver,
The ſame falſe perjur'd Man. Draw, or by Heaven,
That now ſhould Thunder and revenge my wrongs,
Thou ſhalt dye ſluggiſhly.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Recall your ſelf,
And do but hear—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: What words a Coward will
Fawn on me with, to keep an abject life,
Not worth the ſaving.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Witneſs all ye Gods
That govern Friendſhip, how unwillingly
I do unty the Knot.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Draw quickly, leſt
It may be known I am the Cretan Prince,
And ſo my juſter Fury be not ſuffer'd
To ſcourge a timorous and perfidious Man.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.l: Though thou ſtand'ſt here an Enemy, and we have
The Pledge of all the Cretan State, yet know
Though all our Iſland's People did look on,
And thou proclaim'ſt thy ſelf to be the Man,
They ſhould not dare to know the Prince, untill
I'd done this Sacrifice to Honour.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: So!
sp.stage: They fight, and wound each other dangerouſly, and then retire, Chariſtus to Lucaſia's Myrtle, and Olyndus to the next adjoyning, and leaning there ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: I have not long to ſtay 'mongſt Mortals now,
And then you may ſearch all thoſe Corners that
You talk'd of in my Heart. But if you find
Ought that is falſhood towards you, or more
Than reverence to Lucaſia, may I want
The Honour of a Grave—Hear O ye Gods,
(Ye Gods whom (but a while) and I am with)
Lucaſia is as ſpotleſs, as the Seat
That you prepare for Virgin Lovers!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I
Have wrong'd thee, my Olyndus, wrong'd thee much,
But do not chide me; there's not life enough
Left in me to make uſe of Admonition.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: If you ſurvive, love your Lucaſia; 'twill
Make your Olyndus happy; for the good
Of the ſurviving Friend, ſome holy men
Say, doth pertain unto the Friend Departed.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Vertuous Lucaſia! and hadſt thou Olyndus
Not been ſo too, my Gods had fought for me;
But I muſt dye—Olyndus.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Heaven forbid
That my Chariſtus periſh! I have only
Strength left to wiſh: If I can creep yet to thee
I'l help thee all I can.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: And I will meet thee;
sp.stage: [They creep one to the other and ſo embrace.]
sp.l: Let us embrace each other yet. The Fates
Preſerve our Friendſhip, and would have us equall,
Equall ev'n in our Angers: we ſhall go
Down equall to the Shades both, two waies equall,
As Dead, as Friends. And when Lucaſia ſhall
Come down unto us (which the Heavens forbid
Should be as yet) I'l not be Jealous there.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. III.
div.stage: To them as they lye groveling, and embracing thus,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Me! Good Heavens! had you the Balſam, Lady,
Now that you told me of, 'twould do ſomegood.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: This is Olyndus, that the honour'd Stranger;
Brave Spirits are a Balſam to themſelves:
There is a Nobleneſs of Mind, that heals
Wounds beyond Salves—look not, but help Philaenis,
Gather the Weapons, and the reſt up quickly;
Where two are wrong'd, I ought to ſuccour both.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: MAdam, ne'r fear your Dream, for that is only
The reliques of your day-time thoughts, that are
Preſerv'd by'our Soul, to make a Scene i'th' Night.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Have you not dream'd the like before?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes thrice.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Why then Paeſtanus now hath periſh'd thrice,
Or elſe y' have ſometimes dream'd in vain.

sp.speaker: Flor.

l.hi: Eumela,

sp.l: I told her this, and that her troubled Sleep;
Were one Love ſtill waking.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Wee'l divert
This anxious fear. Reach me the Lute Eumela.
Have you not heard how Venus did complain
For her belov'd Adonis? The young Poet,
That was deſit'd to give a Language to
Th' afflicted Goddeſs, thought her words were theſe.

lg.l: VVAke my Adonis, do not dye;

l.hi: One Life's enough for thee and I.
Where are thy words? thy wiles?
Thy Loves, thy Frowns, thy ſmiles?
Alas in vain I call;
One death hath ſnatch'd 'em all:
Yet Death's not deadly in that Face,
Death in thoſe Looks it ſelf hath Grace.
'Twas this, 'twas this I feard
When thy pale Ghoſt appear'd;

lg.l: This I preſag'd when thund'ring Jove

l.hi: Tore the beſt Myrtle in my Grove;
When my ſick Roſe-buds loſt theïr ſmell,
And from my Temples untouch'd fell;
And 'twas for ſome ſuch thing
My Dove did hang her Wing.
Whither art thou my Deity gone?

lg.l: Venus in Venus there is none.

l.hi: In vain a Goddeſs now am I
Only to Grieve, and not to dye.
But I will love my Grief,
Make Tears my Tears relief;
And Sorrow ſhall to me

lg.l: A new Adonis be.
And this no Fates can rob me of, whiles I
A Goddeſs am to Grieve. and not to Dye.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Madam, they ſay 'twas in this very Grove
The Goddeſs thus complain'd.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. V.
div.stage: To them Philaenis with a couple of Napkins.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: HOw now Philaenis?
Are you turn'd Sewer to the Lady-Errant?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Lady I'm ſent to wipe away the Bloud
From theſe two Myrtles.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Bleſs me! what Bloud Philaenis?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I hope the Song will not prove ominous.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis fit we have ſome Wars at home too, elſe
My Lady would have no employment left.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What Wars? whoſe Bloud?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A pair of froward Lovers,
Olyndus, and the Stranger, fought, it ſeems,
Here till they almoſt kill'd themſelves: and when
Neither did fear, but both did faint, it ſeems
Olyndus lean'd there, and the Stranger there,
And with their Blouds beſmear'd the Trees a little;
We did not think your Highneſs ſhould have ſeen it.
sp.stage: They riſe amaz'd, the Princeſs repairs to the Tree where Chariſtus bled, and Eumela to the Tree where ber Olyndus bled.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is this Olyndus way of mingling Souls?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Is this the Others Enterchange of Breaſts?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Heavens! durſt your Olyndus thus?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: O Heav'ns,
And O ye Gods too! durſt that other this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Did he then ſtay behind for this Eumela?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: And did he leave his Country to deſtroy
One worth it all, here in our very Boſoms?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: H' has ruin'd one, whoſe like if Nature will
Shew to the World again, ſhe muſt lay up,
And gather, till ſhe hath ſtore enough of Graces
To throw into the World.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Olyndus ſtood
As high, and brave as he, his Enemy had
But this advantage of him, that he was
A Cretan, as by Birth, ſo too in Faith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Were he the Birth of ſome unſhelter'd Cottage,
He were yet fairer in the Eye o'th' World
Than e'r Olyndus could have been, in that
He was a Princeſs's thoughts; 'twas I that lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Although the Name of Princeſs be upon you,
And ſigns you Dread, and Soveraign, yet I muſt
Tell you that Love's a Princeſs too in me,
And ſtamps as much Heroick Majeſty
Upon my Thoughts, as Birth hath done on yours.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Though, as a Princeſs, I could make thy Love
And thee forgotten Names, yet I depoſe
My ſelf, and am thy Equall.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Tis no need
That you deſcend, Love carries up Eumela
To be as high as is her Princeſs, and
In this ſad Fate placeth her equall with
Her Dread Lucaſia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hear, hear this brave man!
And if thou liv'ſt revenge it on Olyndus.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: And thou the Spirit of my dear Olyndus,
Be thou ſtill worthy, ſtill thy ſelf. Speak thou
O Nature, was there not the ſame clay knead
To make our Hearts? did not the ſame Fire kindle
Our Souls? and thou, O Love, was't not the ſame
Metall that wounded both? you muſt not count
The Princeſs into th' worth of your Affection;
Love when he ballanceth the Hearts that come
Under his Power, caſts not in their Births,
Fortunes, and Titles.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Would ſome powerfull God
Would change our Perſons, and make thee Lucaſia,
And me Eumela, that I might avow
The juſtice of my Love in ſpight of State.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Forbear Eumela.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis the Princeſs ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Nor Prince, nor Subject ſpeaks, but Love in both.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: They leave their Trees, and repair to Macheſſa.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: HEre's one can tell you all.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Say, good Macheſſa,
How doth the Stranger?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Lives Olyndus yet?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Both live, but wounded much, yet hopes of both;
For they are Friends, and as their Minds have clos'd,
Their wounds may ſhortly too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How fell they out?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: I heard the Stranger, Madam, thus confeſs,
As our Olyndus did embrace him; Thou
Wert honourable, my Olyndus, ever;
But I was foul, and Jealous: then Olyndus
Fell on his Neck, told him 'twas only heat,
And ſtrength of Love; and vow'd he'd never tell
The cauſe and ground o'th' Quarrell: but the Stranger
Swore by his Gods, and Altars, that he would
Go find, and tell, and ask the Deity
Forgiveneſs firſt, then him—I heard no more
But only ſighs from either.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Twas too much—
That I ſhould throw away my grieffor one
That durſt have ſuch a thought! Chariſtus, you
And I are both deceiv'd in one another;
And, poor Olyndus, deerly haſt thou paid
For both our Errors—
—Macheſsa, as you love me
Be carefull of Olyndus, for the other—
My care hath been more than he's worth already—

sp.speaker: Flo.

l.hi: Eumela,

sp.l: The Princeſs is much troubled, pray heav'n your freedom
Did not offend her Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I hope it did not:
Madam, if too much Love made me forge;
And paſs the bounds of Duty, humbly, I beg
Your Graces pardon, beſeeching you t'impute
My folly to my Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Call't not Paſſion,
'Twas Reaſon to Conteſt: Love's Kingdom is
Founded upon a Parity; Lord, and Subject,
Maſter, and Servant, are Names baniſh'd thence;
They wear one Fetter all, or, all one Freedom.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: There was ſome Spirit ſpake within me, 'twas—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas! excuſe it not: all that do Love,
In that they love, are equall, and above none,
None, but thoſe only whom the God denies
The honour of his Wound—Eumela, hear me,
Chariſtus is grown foul, and thy Olyndus
Is now my Martyr, for my ſake he bleeds,
And I, for this, will make Chariſtus know,
That he, who doubts his Friend, is his own Foe.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Adraſte, Lucaſia, Malthora, Florina, Eumela, Coſmeta, Pandena, Rhodia, Macheſſa, ſate as at Parliament.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: MY Lady Martiall, and the reſt Mercuriall,
Woman's the Gem of Heaven, in which Nature
Hath carv'd the Univerſe in leſs Characters;
A Peece of ſuch Invention, and ſuch Art,
That, where as in one common lazy Mold
Made for diſpatch, ſhe caſts, and thruſts out Men,
As ſome things done in haſte, ſhe may be ſaid
To build, and ſend forth us; yet (howſoever
It comes about) in all foretimes and Ages
Councels and Senats have excluded us,
Thinking us like thoſe finer Wits, which ſpin
Themſelves into ſuch ſubt'le Fancies, that
They are too Curious to be employ'd,
Being as far from Service, as from Groſsneſs:
But this hath been from Errour, not from Tryall:
Grant me their Compoſition ſtronger, grant me
Their Bodie's ruder, and more fit for Wars,
Which ſome yet here do happily contradict,
I cannot yet conceive, why this ſhould bind us
To be their Slaves; our Souls are Male, as theirs.
That we have hitherto forborn t'aſſume
And manage Thrones, that hitherto we have not
Challeng'd a Soverainty in Arts, and Arms,
And writ our ſelves Imperiall, hath been
Mens Tyranny, and our Modeſty. Being then
Nature did mean us Soveraigns, but croſs Fate
(Envious of her, willing that nothing ſhould
Be perfect upon Earth) ſtill kept us under;
Let us, i'th' name of Honour, riſe unto
The pitch of our Creation. Now's the time;
The beſt and ableſt men are abſent, thoſe
That are left here behind are either Fooles,
Or Wiſe men overgrown, which is all one
Aſſert your ſelves into your Liberty then,
Stand firm, and high, put theſe good Reſolutions
Forth into Action: then, in ſpight of Fate,
A Female Hand ſhall turn the Wheel of State.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Inſpir'd Adraſte!

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Moſt divine Adraſte!

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: If that you reliſh this let Miſtris Speaker
On to the reſt.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: On, on, on, on, on, on!

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Moſt Willing, moſt Agreeing, moſt Potent,
And moſt free Ladies, &c.—
'Tis fit all things ſhould be reduc'd unto
Their Primeve Inſtitution, and firſt Head;
Woman was then as much as Man, thoſe Stones
Which Pyrrha caſt, made as fair Creatures as
Deucalion's did: that his ſhould be ſet up
Carv'd, and Ador'd, but hers kept down, and trampled,
Came from an ancient Injury; what Oracle, and
What voice from Heaven commanded that?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Moſt true!
Obſerve that Ladies.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sibyl's Leaf by Juno!

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: He that ſaies Woman is not fit for Policy,
Doth give the Lie to Art; for what man hath
More ſorts of Looks? more Faces? who puts on
More ſeverall Colours? Men, compar'd in this,
Are only Dough bak'd Women; not as once
Maliciouſly one call'd us Dough-bak'd Men.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: 'Tis no ſingle
Voice; the whole Sex ſpeaks in her.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Some few yet
Do ſpeak againſt our Paſſions, but with greater;
Rail at our Lightneſs, but 'tis out of Humour;
Rather Diſeaſe than Reaſon; they being ſuch
As wipe off what they ſpit. For Heav'n forbid
That any ſhould vouchſafe to ſpeak againſt us
But rough Philoſophers, and rude Divines,
And ſuch like dull Profeſſions. But wee I now
Shew them our Paſſions are our Reaſons Edge,
And that, which they call Lightneſs, only is
An Art to turn our ſelves to ſeverall Points.
Time, Place, Minds, People, all things now concur
To re-eſtate us there where Nature plac'd us:
Not a Male more muſt enter Cyprus now.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: No, nor an Eunuch, nothing that hath been
Male heretofore.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: No, nor Hermophrodite;
Nothing that is half Male. A little Spark
Hath often kindled a whole Town; we muſt
Be cautelous in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: That then they may not
Regain the Iſland, all the Havens muſt
Be ſtor'd, and guarded.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Very fit they ſhould.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Next to the Havens, Caſtles out of hand
Muſt be repair'd, Bulwarks, and Forts, and Sconces
Be forthwith rear'd.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: 'Tis time we were about them.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Arms then muſt be bought up, and Forces rais'd;
Much, much is to be done—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why let Macheſſa
About it ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I ſee agreeing Minds,
Your Hearts and Courage very ready, but
Where is the Nerve and Sinew of this Action?
Where ſhall we have the Mony to do this?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Wee'l give our hair for Cordage, and our fineſt
Linnen for Sails, rather than this Deſign
Shall be once daſh'd for want.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: There's much already
Come in—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And more doth dayly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Hearts and Purſes
Concur unto the Action.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: We have Notes
Of the particular Contributions.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Her Majeſty would have you read 'em, that
She may know what to truſt to.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: From the Temple
We do expect ten dozen of Chalices,
But they are hid, or elſe already gone—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: This is not what you have, but what y'have not.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: We tell you this, that you mayn't take it ill,
That we ha'n't borrow'd ſome o'th' Holy Plate.
Well then, to what we have—Firſt from the Court
Ten Veſſels of Corinthian Braſs, with divers
Peeces of Polyclet, and Phyd • as,
Parrhaſius, Zeuxes, and Protogenes,
Apelles, and ſuch like great Maſter-hands.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Statues, and Pictures do but little good
Againſt the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Pray y' hear it out:
Rich Cabinets then, which, though they do contain
Treaſure immenſe and large, have nothing yet
Within them richer than themſelves.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: What hold they?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Pearls, Rubies, Emralds, Amethyſts, and Saphirs,
Cryſolits, Jaſpers, Diamonds, two whereof
Do double the twelfth Caract: beſides Sparks
Enough to ſtick the Roof o'th' Banquetting Houſe,
And make it ſeem an Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: VVell, on Coſmeta.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Twelve ſtanding Goblets, two more rich and maſſy,
The one bears Bacchus ſitting on a Vine,
Squeezing out Purple liquor, Th' other hath
Silenus riding on his patient Beaſt,
And Satyrs dancing after him. More yet,
Twelve other leſs engraven with leſs Stories,
As Loves, and Months, and Quarters of the year,
Nymphs, Shepheards, and ſuch like—This from the Court.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: VVhat from the City?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Purple Robes, and Furs
In great abundance—Baſons and large Ewers,
Flagons, and Diſhes, Plates, and Voyders, all
Rich and unwieldy. And beſides all this,
Gold Chains, and Caudle-Cups innumerable.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: The Contribution's much—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But yet not ended—
Twelve City Ladies ſend us word, they have
Twelve Iron Cheſts, and rib'd with Iron too,
VVherein they do ſuſpect there lies a Mine,
That hath not ſeen the Sun for ſix Olympiads.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Let 'em be got in ſuddenly; we muſt
Be hot and eager in our undertakings.
The VVealth's enough; the Eaſt was overrun
By the bold Macedonian Boy with leſs.
VVas't not Macheſſa? But I pray you nothing
From the poor Country Villagers?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Very little;
Hoop-rings, and Childrens VVhiſtles, and ſome forty
Or fifty dozen of gilt-Spoons, that's all.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Let it be haſtily deliver'd all
Into her Majeſties Treaſury.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Under favour,
We think Macheſſa would be very fit
Both to take in, and to disburſe.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: It is not
For any private Intereſt that She asks it,
But for the Publike good.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Perhaps. But yet
The People will think better, if it be
Entruſted in a Subject's hand, and Hers
Eſpecially who never had a Husband—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: No, nor a Child as yet.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Why be it ſo;
You ſhall diſpoſe't Macheſſa.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: I conſider
The truſt you give me: ſee the weight, and Nature,
The Price and Moment of the Cauſe; Know next
My Order binds me not to be endow'd
With any Wealth or Utenſill, beſides
My Steed, my Habit, Arms, and Page; To which
When I prove falſe, let him that weaves my Story
(Whether he be a Courtier, or perhaps
A Scholar that writes worſe) bring me no higher
Than to ſcratch'd Faces, and ſuch Suburb brangles.
Truth is the Eſſence of our Order, we
Who are Errants cannot deceive and Be.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Let us away: though the Male-Gods may frown,
The Female part of Heaven is ſure our own

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Noble Macheſſa all your deeds I ſee
sp.stage: Ex. Adraſt. Cal. &c. Manent Eu. Macheſſa.
sp.l: Tend to the Scope of Honour.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Were ſhe ſeated
Upon the top of ſome high craggy Rock,
Whoſe Head were in the Country of the Thunder,
Guarded with watchfull Dragons, I will climb,
And raviſh her from thence, to have my Name
Turn'd o'r from Age to Age, as ſomething that
Ought to outlive the Phaenix, and dye only
With Men and Time.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Though you Court Danger thus,
I hope you will not ſcorn bright Glory, if
She come an eaſier way.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: I look to her,
Not to her Cloaths, and Habit.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Will you be
Famous in Hiſtory then? fill ſwelling Volumes
With your ſole Name? be read aloud, and high
I'th' Cyprian Annals? and live freſh upon
The Tongue of Fame for ever? will you ſtand
High on your Steed in Braſs, and be at once
The ſtop of Strangers, and the Natives Worſhip,
By one fair Peacefull Action?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Brave Eumela,
To ſay I'l do't is lazy; it is done.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Tis the Queen's ſute beſides,
And She ſhall thank you.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Honour is my Queen,
And my Deeds thank themſelves. But ſay, Eumela,
Quickly, what is't?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Why only ſend this Wealth,
That's put into your hands, unto the Army,
And ſo defeat this folly that they here
So eagerly purſue.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: By Heav'n I'll firſt
Scatter the Aſhes of my Anceſters,
Burn and demoliſh Temples, or pull down
The Statue of our Goddeſs, whiles her ſelf
Stood with the proudeſt thunder to defend it;
You ought to thank me, that you have popos'd it,
And yet ſtill live.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: But pray you reaſon it.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Follies of idle Creatures! who e'r heard
Of Ladies Errant yet that ſtood to Reaſon?
But you that brag of Books, and Reading, and
I know not what unneceſſary Learning,
Tell me, did brawny Hercules, who wand'red
I'th' Lion's skin, and Club, or well-ſet Theſeus
That trod his ſteps, e'r do the like?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: No. VVomen
Ne'r came to ſuch a pitch of danger yet
As to be baniſh'd all: then who e'r truſted
Theſeus, or Hercules with ten Drachmas? who
Could know their Minds that way? This ſingle deed
VVill make Macheſſa go beyond his Pillars,
And th' other's Fame. They quell'd but ſingle Robbers,
You will defeat thouſands of Rebels. They
Help'd ſome poor Village, or ſome Town perhaps,
You will redeem a Nation.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Thouſay'ſt ſomething;
But I ſhall break my faith

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: To whom? to thoſe
That have before broke theirs unto their Prince?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: They'l curſe me too.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: As bold Macheſſa hunts not
The Praiſe of People, ſo ſhe can contemn
Their Curſe, when ſhe doth well. Conſider too
Nations will curſe you more if you aſſiſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: But 'tis againſt my Order to deceive.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Tis more againſt your Order to aſſiſt
Rebellious Perſons 'gainſt their King. Beſides,
Doth not your Oath enjoyn you to relieve
Diſtreſſed men? who more diſtreſſed now
Than is the King, and th' Army? fear not words;
You are not Treacherous unto them, but faithfull
Unto your ſelf. Why ſtands this Helmet here?
VVhy do you wear this Fauchion? to what uſe
Carry this Javelin?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Not to help women; no,
Men are my Oath. All ſhall be ſent Eumela,
The King muſt have it: wee'l be famous—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: But
You muſt be ſecret 'till it all come in.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: And you'l aſſiſt me in the ſending of't?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Take you no care for that, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: But will
The Queen not take it ill?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Tis her great fear,
You'l ſcarce be brought to yeeld it up. Away,
Go, and delude 'em on, y' are ſafe, and may
Deceive in Conſcience now.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Bellona bleſs thee!

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: But how ſhall we now conveigh it to 'em?

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. II.
div.stage: To her Philondas and Paeſtanus as having ſtoln from the Army.

sp.l: —Heav'n's of the Plot! No fitter men. Jove bleſs me!
My Lord Philondas, and my Lord Paeſtanus!
This your appearance to me's like the firſt
Appearance to a new admitted Prieſt,
And I am quite as doubtfull now as he,
Not knowing whether 't be my fancy, or
The God, that makes the Viſion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dear Eumela,
Thou know'ſt we do appear to Ladies ſtill
In very fleſh and bloud. Though we may talk
Of ſpirituall Love, my Lord, and I, you know,
Could ne'r creep in at Key-holes yet; I'm ſure
We pay for th' opening of the doors, Eumela.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: My Lord you make Paeſtanus bluſh.

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: I hope
