I am not ſo ill bred Eumela.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Troth
The Camp hath ſpoyl'd you both. The Cretan Ladies
They ſay are far beyond our Cyprus Dames.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes to cleave Logs, and carry Burthens.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: But
I mean for Beauty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In whoſe Eyes, Eumela?
In the Town-Buls?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: They ſay the Gods have chang'd
Shapes, to come down, and viſit 'em.

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: 'Twas that
They might be like 'em then.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: For Jove could never
Be a fit Husband for 'em, till he had
Got horns, and hoofs.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Saw you no Children there?

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: What then Eumela? ha'n't you read of Creatures
That have Conceiv'd by th' Air?—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Don't think of any
Such thing as man? The Wind and Sun Eumela,
Get all the Children there; that makes 'em bluſter,
And rage ſo furiouſly when they are old.

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: Come, we loſe time; where is Malthora prethee?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Anſwer him not; by Venus, theſe young Husbands
Are as impatient as a hungry Courtier,
Or a rich Heir come newly to his Means;
Do you hear me ask for Florina yet?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Tis not in faſhion, Sir, to love your Lady—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: At leaſt you ought not to profeſs it.

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: I
Dare ſwear, though none profeſſeth leſs, yet none
Loves more than you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis i'th' dark then;
Day-light and Love are two things. But, Eumela,
What do they do for Men now we are abſent?
Do they take Phyſick, or elſe Pray?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: My Lord,
Their Griefs are in your places.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Have their ſighs
Got Limbs, and Bodies? Can their ſadneſs give 'em
Comfort at Midnight?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: They poſſeſs it with
A kind of ſweetneſs, are ſo tender of it,
That ſhould they part with it, they'd think they had
A ſecond loſs.

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: How can they paſs away
Their time with that?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Why 'tis as neceſſary
To them as Friend, or Confident:

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: But tell me
How does Malthora bear it?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Sir, ſhe finds
That ſolitude in her ſelf, that others do
Look for in Deſarts.

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: Come my Lord, let'sgo
And help 'em to ſigh for us.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: They're to come
Hither my Lord: pray ſtand behind theſe hangings
Till I diſcover the whole Scene; In quickly.
Here, here they come.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: BLeſs me Eumela! I
Muſt get me Mens apparell, and go ſee
How all things ſtand abroad; I did but cloſe
Mine Eyes, and preſently me thought the Ghoſt
Of my Paeſtanus did appear before me,
Wounded, and bloudy, and as ſoon as I
Went to embrace him, vaniſh'd into air.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: You are ſo fearfull, Madam, and do fancy
Danger and death ſo ſtrongly, that if he
Were at this inſtant preſent here before you
You'd not beleeve your Eyes. Madam Florina
What's that you look on ſo?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: It is, Eumela,
The Picture of my Lov'd Philondas, as
He had his Armour on, (and O the Heav'ns
That he ſhould ever be in ſuch a Habit)
But Fates would have it ſo; 'twas young Protogenes
Took it before he went. Me thinks it ſometimes
Doth move, and alter Colour, and endeavour
To get looſe, and come out.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Have you the Picture
Of your Lord Madam too?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes here, Eumela,
Drawn by the ſame hand: is't not very like him?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Methinks they're neither true: I've both their Statues,
Though not in Armour, and as I remember
They don't agree with them.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pray y' let's examine
To paſs the time a while.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I've newly put 'em
Both into Habits, and me thinks they look
So freſh, and lively, that I might miſtake 'em,
But that I know they're abſent; look you here.
sp.stage: She draws the bangings and ſhews 'em.
sp.l: Does not this look more like Philondas far,
And this more like Paeſtanus than the Tablets?
You muſt not come too near: I'l leave y' a while
To view, and judge.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Good Heav'ns! my Lord Philondas!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My dear Paeſtanus!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am come you ſee
A prety jant here to fulfil the longing
Of a young Novice-Husband.

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: The firſt day
That Hymen joyn'd us, brought not truer joy
Unto my Soul than this.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: MY Lords, the Queen
Is come to make a viſit to your Ladies:
What will you do?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Go and conduct her in.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Now Madam? does your Husband vaniſh, when
You offer to embrace him?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O Eumela
He's gone already. This his ſhort appearance
Is only as th' appearance of a Star
To one that's periſhing in a Tempeſt.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis
Only to let us die with ſome more Comfort.
Were they to ſtay Eumela—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: This diſjoyning
Of Bodies, only is to knit your hearts;
You'l form their Pictures in your Thoughts perhaps,
And once or twice more look behind the Hangings.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Peace good Eumela! here's the Queen.

sp.speaker: Adr.

l.hi: CHariſtus,

sp.l: Heir to the Cretan Kingdom loſt ſay you?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes, and ſuſpected to lye hid in Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: And this is that doth ſtop the War?

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: This, and
Th' Equality of Forces.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Do our men
Awake, and rouze themſelves?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Rich noble Spirits,
And Minds that have kept Altars burning ſtill,
To Glory break out dayly, ſhe wing how
Peace and Religion did not ſink, but calm 'em:
This blaſt will ſwell 'em big, and high, and make 'em
Ride Conquerours o'r the Flouds.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: They do not ſleep then?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: No, nor watch lazily; the World will ſee,
He, whoſe bleſt goodneſs hath kept War from us,
Hath not took Courage from us too; When his
Sad ſtudy'd Councels did remove the danger,
They did not then remove the Mind. The Arm
Of this days Cyprus, if provok'd, will ſtrike
As deep as Cyprus ſix Olympiads backwards,
And the unquiet Cretan ſhall appear
But as he did of old, our Exerciſe,
More than our Foe: a people that we ſuffer
To breath, and be, to keep our ſelves in breath.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: What doth the King?

sp.speaker: Paeſt.
sp.l: More than the meaneſt souldier,
Yet ſtill comes freſh from Actions: his Commands
Are great, but his Examples greater ſtill.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: With his uncover'd head he dares the Thunder,
Slights hail and ſnow, and wearies out a Tempeſt,
Then after all he ſhakes himſelf, and gives
Rain, as the Heavens did before, but with
A more ſerene Aſpect. He doth exact
Labour, and hardneſs, hunger, heat, and cold,
And duſt, as his Prerogatives, and counts them
Only his ſerious Pleaſures; Others Wars
Are not ſo manly as his Exerciſes,
And pitch'd Fields often are more eaſie ſervice
Than his meer Preparations.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: 'Tis enough;
Y'have ſpoke a Compoſition, ſo made up
Of Prince and Souldier, that th' admiring World
May imitate, not equall. Come, my Lords,
I have a buſineſs to employ you back with.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs, had not this Action been
Tainted with private Intereſt, but born
From zeal unto the Publique, then it might
Have been read Valour, as it is, it will
Be ſtil'd but Fury.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Madam it had then
Been only Valour, now 'tis Love and Valour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: VVhere thoſe Religious Names, King, Country, Father,
Are trampled over, can you call it Valour?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If trampled o'r for you. To hazard all
Theſe holy Names, of Subject unto King,
Of Prince to Country, and of Son to Father,
And whil'ſt I ſpar'd to ſhed the ſmalleſt drop
Of Bloud, that might be once call'd yours, to have
That ignominious Name of Coward hurl'd on me,
And take up all their Places; what elſe is it
But to eſteem your ſelf a Prize, that doth
Abſolve me from all theſe, and make me ſtand
Above the rate of mortals.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: Father, Country,
State, Fortunes, Common wealth, th'are Names that Love
Is not concern'd it; that looks higher ſtill,
And overſees all theſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is not Love then;
For that, as it is Valiant, ſo it is
Juſt, Temperate, Prudent, ſummons all thoſe Noble
Heroick Habits into one rich Maſs,
And ſtamps them Honour.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: But that Honour is
A Valour beyond that of Mortals, ſtriving
Who ſhall poſſeſs moſt of this Mole-hill Earth.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: That Honour is a Juſtice, that doth ſee
Meaſures, and Weights, Axes, and Rods below it.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: A Temperance not concern'd in Meats, and Wines.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: A Prudence that doth write Chariſtus now
A better Patriot, than the ſober'ſt Stateſman
That plots the good of Crete.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If he that cares not
For things, be thence above them; if he ſees
More nobly, that doth draw the Veyl before
His Eyes to Lower Objects, then Chariſtus
Soares high, and nothing ſcapes him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Fair Lucaſia,
I am not ſo immodeſt, as to challenge
The leaſt of theſe my ſelf: but yet in that
I love your Vertues, they are all mine own.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And yet you fear'd I was anothers, whom
I durſt not publiquely avow. Do y'think
My Love could ſtould ſtoop to ſuch Contrivances?
Or if I meant a ſubject of ſuch worth,
I needed to pretend a Prince?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: It is not
Lucaſia's Love, that dares not call the Eye
Of Day to try it: But where Love's engag'd
To ſuch a Treaſure as your ſelf, what can
Be thought ſecure? It ſtands and watches ſtill,
And fears it's very helps; could any love
Lucaſia and be careleſs, 'twere a fault
Would make him not deſerve her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Could you then
Think I could be ſo impious unto Love
As to divide Eumela and Olyndus?
Or elſe ſo treacherous unto Friendſhip, as
To part Eumela and my ſelf? Being Hearts
Are Temples, and both ſorts of Love moſt Sacred,
To have wrong'd either had been Sacrilege
Worthy the horrid'ſt Thunder.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Love drinks in
All that may feed ſuſpicion, but is deaf
To what may clear it; 'tis engag'd ſo much
To th' Object, that it views the Object only,
And weighs not what attends it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Where the Heart
Offends, you blame the Paſſion. Love it ſelf
Is never undiſcreet, but he that Loves.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Wiſdome and Love at once were never yet
Permitted to a God, I muſt not then
Preſume they meet in me. If Love admits
Diſcretion, if it Ponder, and Conſider,
Search, and Compare, and Judge, and then Reſolve,
'Tis Policy, not Affection: give it Eyes,
Counſell, and Order, and it ceaſeth. What
Though it firſt brake from out the Chaos? 'twas
To make another in the Creature. Diſtance,
Figure, and Lineament are things that come
From ſomething more Advis'd; Love never leads,
It ſtill tranſports. The Motions which it feels
Are Fury, Rapture, Extaſie, and ſuch
As thruſt it out full of Inſtinct, and Deity,
To meet what it deſires.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas I it ſelf
Hath Eyes, but 'tis our Blindneſs that doth veyl them:
If Love could not conſiſt with Wiſdome, then
The World were govern'd by one generall Malneſs.

sp.speaker: Olynd.
sp.l: 'Tis not deni'd but that we may have Wiſdom
Before we Love, as men may have good Eyes
Before they fix them on the Sun: but dwell they
A while upon it, and they ſtraight grow blind
From thoſe admired Beauties.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But if Love
Do not conſider, why then doth it fear?
Why doth it form Chimaeras to it ſelf,
And ſet up Thought 'gainſt Thought? why is 'c alike
Tortur'd with Truth, and Falſhood? why afflicted
As much from Doubts, as Certainties?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: This is
Not from Diſtruſt, but Care; Love is not perfect
Till it begins to fear. It doth not know
The worth of that it ſeeks, unleſs it be
Anxious, and troubled for it: And this is
Not any thought of Blemiſh in the thing
It loves, but only Study to preſerve it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Who puts a Snake 'mongſt Flowers to preſerve 'em▪
Or who pours Poyſon into Cryſtall that
It may be kept from cracking? Jealouſe
What art thou? thou could'ſt not come down from Heav'n;
For no ſuch Monſters can inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Nor can it ſpring from Hell; for it is born
Of Love, and there is nought but Hate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray y' tell me
Who joyn'd it unto Love? who made them ſwear
So firm a Friendſhip?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: The ſame Deity
That joyn'd the Sun and Light, the ſame that knits
The Life and Spirit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Theſe preſerve each other:
But that doth twine and wreath it ſelf about
Our growing Loves, as Ivy bout the Oak;
We think it ſhelters, when (alas!) we find
It weakens, and deſtroys.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: It is not Jealouſie
That ruins Love, but we our ſelves, who will not
Suffer that fear to ſtrengthen it; Give way
And let it work, 'twill fix the Love it ſprings from
In a ſtaid Center.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What it works I know not,
But it muſt needs ſuppoſe Defect in one,
Either Defect of Merit in the Lover,
Or in the Lov'd, of Faith; you cannot think
That I give Others Favours, when your ſelf
Boaſt ſuch a ſtore of Merits.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O Lucaſia,
Rather than be ſo impious as to think
That you want Faith, I muſt confeſs a want
Of Merit in my ſelf; (which would there were not.)
And being it is ſo, I was compell'd
To fear leſt one more worthy than my ſelf
Might throw me from my happineſs. Conſider
That you are born t' enrich the Earth, and then
If you will have one Love and not be Jealous,
You muſt convert your Eye upon your Eye,
Make your own Heart Court your own Heart, and be
Your ſelf a ſervant to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But doth not
This Paſſion ceaſe at laſt?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: It ceaſeth to
Diſturb, but ſtill remains to quicken Love;
As Thunder ceaſeth when 't hath purg'd the Air,
And yet the Fire which caus'd it ſtill remains
To make it move the livelier.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Were it quiet,
What Hand, Chariſtus, would More ſweetly move
The Orbs of this our Iſland? who fetch in
More frequent Conqueſts? and who more become
The Triumphs than your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Beleeve Chariſtus
Dreams; Errours, falſe Opinions, ſlippery Hopes,
And Jealous Fears are now his Spoyl, his Captives,
And follow Love's Triumphant Chariot, which
His Soul ſits high in, and o'rlooks the vain
Things of this lower World.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Lucaſia did
Only retire, not flie; Let's to the Grove,
And by the Conſummation of our Loves
Under thoſe Myrtles (which as yet perhaps
Preſerve the bluſhing Marks of thoſe your Angers)
Appeaſe th' offended Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: This your Union
Will make your Kingdoms joyn; Cyprus and Crete
Will meet in your Embraces.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Our Hearts are
Love's ord'nary Employment: 'tis a Dart
Of a more ſcattering Metall that ſtrikes you;
When he wounds Princes, he wounds Nations too.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div.stage: Pandena, Coſmeta, Rhodia, meeting Macheſſa and Philaenis.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: LAdy Macheſſa, opportunely met.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What ſtore of Arms prepat'd?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: The Country's layd;
Spits, Andirons, Racks, and ſuch like Utenſils
Are in the very Act of Metamophoſis;
Art is now ſitting on them, and they will
Be hatch'd to Engins ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Pray y' how doth
The Muſter-Roule encreaſe?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: As faſt as Chloe
Can take their Names; we ſhall be all great Women.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray y' what Reward ſhall you and I have Lady?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Why I will be the Queen o'th' Amazons,
And thou o'th' Pigmies.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I, but who ſhall place us
In the Amazonian, and Pigmean Throne?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Who but our Swords Philaenis? when we have
Setled the Government here at home, we will
Lead out an Army 'gainſt thoſe Warlike Dames,
And make 'em all our Vaſſals.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Theſe left handed
Ladies are notable Politicians.
The King of Monomotapa you may
Be ſure will be your Enemy, or elſe
The Book deceives me. But the Agags they
Will ſure be for you.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Who may the Agags be?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why a black ugly People, that do turn
The inſide of their Eye-lids outward, that
They may look lovely; if they catch the Amazons,
They ſowce 'em ſtraight, as we do Pig, by quarters,
Or elſe do pickle 'em up for Winter Sallads.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: How did you come by all this Knowledge Phil?
You are a learned Page.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lady, do y' think
I never read to th' Women in the Nurs'ry?
But will you loſe one of your Breaſts? tis pitty
That your left Pap ſhould be burnt off.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Why Gyrl?
What uſe will there be of it?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: To give ſuck.
You muſt go ſeek out ſome brave Alexander,
And beg ſome half a dozen of Children of him,
Or elſe you'l be no true bred Amazon.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Muſt they have Macedonian Fathers then?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I think the Amazonian Queen doth ſwear
To no ſuch Article when She is Crown'd;
But ord'narily they do ſo; yet howe'r
Your Grace may ſend for the three Courtiers,
That you deliver'd from theſe Ladies here,
They would be glad to be employ'd in any
Such State-affairs. But I'd almoſt forgot
The Pigmies Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Have you read of them too?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Though ſome ſay that their Souls are only ſtopt
Into their Bodies, juſt as ſo much Quick-ſilver
Is put into hot Loves, to make 'em dance
As long as th' heat continues; yet, beleeve it,
They are a ſubt'le Nation, a moſt ſhrew'd
Adviſing People.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: How'i you then ſubdue them?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By Policy, ſet Hays, and Traps, and Springs,
And Pitfals for 'em. And if any do
Dwell in the Rocks, make holes upon the top
As deep as Cups, and fill 'em up with Wine;
You ſhall have one come preſently, and ſip,
And when he finds the ſweetneſs, cry Chin, Chin:
Then all the reſt good Fellows ſtraight come out,
And tipple with him till they fall aſleep;
Then we may come and pack 'em up in Hampers,
Or elſe in Hand-baskets, and carry 'em whither
We pleaſe our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: A notable Stratagem!
You'l never leave your Policies Phil.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But yet
We muſt draw out ſome Souldiers howe'r.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: There's no great need of souldiers; Their Camp's
No larger than a Ginger-bread Office.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And the Men little bigger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What half Heretick
Book tels you that?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: The greateſt ſort they ſay
Are like ſtone-pots with Beards that do reach down
Unto their knees.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: They're carri'd to the Wars then
As Chickens are to Market, all in Dorſers,
Some thirty Couple on a Horſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You read
Only Apocryphall Hiſtory. Beleeve me
They march moſt formally: I know't there will
Be work enough for Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Mach
sp.l: Wee'l train up
All the young Wenches of the City here
On purpoſe for this Expedition,
A • d't ſhall be call'd the Female War.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I fear
They won't be ſtrong enough to go againſt 'em;
They have an Enemy doth vex 'em more
Than Horſe or Man can.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Who, the Cranes you mean?
I'l beg a Patent of Her Majeſty
To take up all that fly about the Country,
For the Pigmean Service

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I, but who
Shall's have to Diſcipline 'em ſo, that we
May fly 'em at them off our fiſts?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: They fly
In a moſt war-like Figure naturally:
However we may have a Net caſt o'r
Th' Artyllery Yard, and ſend for th' Gentleman
That bridles Stags, and makes 'em draw Caroches,
Hee'l exerciſe 'em in a Month or two,
And bring 'em to it eaſily.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We muſt carry
Six or ſev'n hundred of Bird-Cages
And Cony-Coopes along with us.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: T' impriſon Rebels, and there feed 'em up
With Milk, and Dazy-roots. I will ſo yerk
The little Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: You muſt not play
The Tyrant o'r the Wretches.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You ſhall ſee
How I'l behave my ſelf. This foreſide blow
Cuts off thrice three, this back-blow thrice three more,
This foreright thruſt ſpits half a dozen of 'em,
Bucklers and all, like ſo many Larkes with Sage
Between them; then this down-right cleaves a ſtubborn
Two-footed Rebell from the Crown o'th' head
Down to the twiſt, and makes him double forked
Like a Turn Stile, or ſome ſuch Engin. Others
I'l knock pall-mall, and make the wretched Caitiffs
Meaſure their length upon their Mother Earth,
And ſo beſtride 'em, and cry Victory.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: And what'l you do, when you are ſeated in
The Throne, to win your Subjects Love Philenis?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'l ſtand upon a Cricket, and there make
Fluent Orations to 'em; call 'em Truſty
And Well-beloved, Loyall, and True Subjects,
And my good People: Then I'l mount on Horſeback,
Shew'em my little Majeſty, and ſcatter
Five or ſix hundred ſingle pence among 'em,
Teach 'em good Language by cleft ſticks, and Bay-leaves,
And Civilize 'em finally by Puppet-Plays.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Moſt ſtudi'd, and advis'd!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The heart of Wiſdome!

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And Soul of Policy!

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Come little Queen,
Wee'l go and make her Majeſty acquainted
With all the Plot; 'twill take her certainly.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Adraſte, Lucaſia, Chariſtus, Olyndus, Eumela, Florina, Malthora, in Myrtle wreathes.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: VVAs all the Treaſure ſhip'd?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: All, but the Pictures,
And Statues, they'r reſerv'd. I ſaw the Luxury,
And wealth of Cyprus ſail. The Souldier doth
By this time gaze upon't.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: The news, Chariſtus,
Of your Adventures here, I dare preſume
Hath joyn'd both Armies now. Me thinks I ſee
The Cyprians ſtanding here, the Cretans there,
And, in a ſpace between them, both Kings meeting
In a moſt ſtrong Embrace, and ſo provoking
Clamors and ſhouts from both ſides, and a joyfull
Clattring of Weapons.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Beautious Queen, your Vertues
Are greater far than Fame; and you your ſelf
Greater than them! Though Gold and Purple do
Adorn your head, yet you have Wove your ſelf
Far richer Diadems from your Royall Acts,
And made your ſelf Immortall by producing
Immortall things. But though your wreath of Vertue
Hath made what e'r the sun beholds in all
His courſe enamor'd by you, yet if I
May pull one ſingle one from out the reſt,
There's none, for which you have more Altars rais'd
Unto your Name, than for that Noble Love,
Whoſe flames you keep ſtill burning in your ſelf,
And cheriſh in all others.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Sir, you have Conquer'd
A Princeſs, and in her a Queen: I am
Th' addition to your Triumph. We ow much
To you Olyndus.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: I can challenge nothing
But my Chariſtus Friendſhip. 'Tis to him
You ow theſe ſeeds of Peace. Although his Father
Appear'd ſo tender of him, that when he
Came hither ſecretly to view the Rites
Of Venus, which Lucaſia then perform'd,
The aged Man haſted to th' Oracle
To know what Fortune ſhould attend his Son,
And, for an unexpected anſwer, did
Baniſh thoſe Prieſts for which our King now fights:
Yet for all this, ev'n in this heat of danger,
H'hath made another Venture, and the Kingdom
Now grieves his ſecond loſs.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Do you know the anſwer
That the God gave to his enquiring Father,
For which the King did baniſh all the Prieſts?

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: I may repeat it now, th' Event aſſures me
It meant you no Misfortune. It was this;
Chariſtus ſhall his Country ſave,

l.hi: If he become his Enemies Slave.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I hope th' Event will not fulfill it.

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: 'Tis
Fulfill'd enough to make an Oracle true.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I hope you have no Enemies, and for Slave
The Gods avert it!

sp.speaker: Olyn.
sp.l: He's Lucaſia's Servant,
There's that fulfill'd; Cyprus is now reputed
The Enemy to Crete; but as for true
And reall Enemies to you Chariſtus,
The World hath none ſo Barbarous; your Vertues
Have under this diſguiſe ſhew'd ſo much Prince,
That they betrai'd you ſtill to any Eye
That could diſcern.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Honour'd Olyndus, you
Out do me ſtill. Friends ſhould be alwaies equall:
You muſt take off, and pare your Vertues, that
You may go even with me. I ow much
To you, Eumela, too.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Her ſervice hath
Preſerv'd the Kingdom, and refounded Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Two Scepters are her Debters.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: But, Eumela,
You might have told me ſooner, that Lucaſia
Began to feel a Paſſion; you ne'r knew
That I deſtroy'd true vertuous Loves; it is
A pleaſure to me to perceive their Buddings,
To know their Minutes of Encreaſe, their Stealths,
And ſilent Growings; and I have not ſpar'd
To help, and bring them on.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: You have ſo favour'd
Agreeing Souls, that all the VVorld confeſſeth
Your own is perfect Harmony. But where
The God is Blind, ſhould not the Creature be
Silent, and Cloſe? That which is bred by whiſpers
VVould dye if once proclam'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If it were any,
It was a fault of Truſt; 'tis more Injuſtice
To betray ſecret Love, than to make known
Counſels of State. Cupid hath his Cabinet,
To which, if any prove unfaithfull, he
Straight wounds him with the Leaden Shaft, and ſo
They live tormented, and dye ſcorn'd.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: No more;
'Tis well: I meant not to Accuſe, but Praiſe.
Have you ſet ſome to watch, and ſignifie
The King's Return?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Three peacefull Courtiers,
Lerinus, and Ganyctor, and Iringus,
Deſir'd that they might bring the News, and ſo
Are gone unto the Port.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: My Ladies, you
I hope will clear up now.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I have too much
Joy to expreſs it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Could you ſee my heart,
You'd view a Triumph there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: ANd't pleaſe your Highneſs
There are three Ladies wait without, who, if
You have a vacant Ear, are come t' inform you
Of ſomething neer concerns the State.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: The old
Vexation's buſie ſtill—Pandena and
Coſmeta, and the other—are they not?
Tell 'em they may come in—How ſhall we do,
Eumela, now to ſtop their Clamour?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Tis eaſie;
There's nothing yet provided; the Return
O'th' King being now ſo ſudden, 'twill amaze 'em,
And make 'em kneel for mercy to you, if
You do but threaten to diſcloſe the Plot.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: YOur buſineſs Ladies?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Pleaſe you to diſmiſs
Thoſe Faces that have Beards?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Fear not, they ſhall not
Betray your Counſels.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Pleaſe your Highneſs then,
There's fear that our Deſign will come to nought,
Our Truſt is falſifi'd.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: VVe came
To ask Macheſſa about VVeapons, and
She preſently demands, how many caſes
Of Knives, what Forks we have, Toſting, or Carving?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Talk we of Swords, ſhe asks what Criſping Pins
And Bodkins we could gueſs might eaſily be
Rais'd through the Common-wealth?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: VVe ſpake of Armour,
She ſtraight replies, ſend in your ſteel Combs, with
The Steels you ſee your Faces in, wee'l quickly
Convert 'em into Greaves, and Gorgets.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: If
This be not treaſon 'gainſt the Female State,
Beleeve not Policy, nor me.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Why ſhe
Was your own choice; you cri'd her up as one
That having neither Child, nor Husband, would
Take to her ſelf the Commonwealth as both.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: We do ſuſpect your ſadneſs ſweet Florina.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And your retir'dneſs too Malthora, (as
Demure as you ſtand here) is deep engag'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Nor is Eumela free.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: VVhence do you gather it?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Pray y' why thoſe Myrtle wreaths? why your Gates dreſt?
And your Doors Crown'd?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In hope our Lords will ſhortly
Enter, and Crown 'em more.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Moſt evident!
Can there be bolder Falſhood? Did we not
Agree to keep out Husbands from our City
And our Minds too? And yet behold there are
Garlands and Flowers prepar'd; and they to be
Receiv'd as Lovers. Husbands are at beſt
But a ſad kind of pleaſure; one good Look,
And a Salute's enough at any time
For the Good-man o'th' Family.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pray y' allow
Affection more Expreſſions; Love doth ceaſe
To be, when that it breaks not out into
Thoſe ſigns of Joy; as Souls ceaſe to be Souls
VVhen they leave off to ſhew their Operations.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: This is no time for vain Philoſophy,
VVe are to have a fine State of it ſhortly,
VVhen Ladies once begin to utter Axioms,
And raiſe a Faction 'gainſt the ſeven Sages.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: ANd't pleaſe your Highneſs, three Embaſſadors,
Sent from the Cretan State, do crave admittance.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Uſher'em in.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: There's life you ſee i'th' bus'neſs;
Let's yet be true. The fame of our Exploit
Already makes us ſought to. There's an Honour
Not uſuall too l'th' Number of 'em; when
Arriv'd there three before from the ſame State?
And't pleaſe you, let Pandena, Rhodia, and I,
Manage their Entertainment?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Do ſo.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It ſhall
All be to th'honour of the Female State.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Prepare your ſelf Pandena; here they come.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE VI.
div.stage: To them Macheſſa uſhering Lerinus, Iringus, and Ganyctor, as Embaſſadors.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: MOſt Gratious, moſt Renowned, and moſt Beautious.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Pray y' be not troubleſome; We're taken up
VVholy with the Affairs o'th' Kingdom now.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: VVhen will your Ladiſhip have a Vacancy?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You are Impertinen; True Politicians
Do never uſe to anſwer on the ſudden.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: It is not now as heretofore; the times
Are grown more wiſe, and more reſerv'd; there are
Matters on foot far greater; you muſt wait—
You are Embaſſadors.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: We ſhould not think ſo,
But that you're pleas'd to tell us ſo; your uſage
Hath a far different Dialect from your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Were there not VVomen in your Kingdom fit
For this Imployment? I perceive your State
Is utterly unfurniſh'd, that it cannot
Send forth three Female Agents.

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: 'Tis not, Madam,
The cuſtome of our Maſter to commit
His Kingdom's ſecrets to a peece of Chryſtall;
That were not to Negotiate, but Betray.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You ſhall meet VVomen here, that are not Cryſtal,
Thoſe that will find out you, and hide themſelves.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You ſhall not need the help of an Interpreter
VVhen we give Audience; Speak what Tongue you will
You ſhall be underſtood, each one of us
Hath more than one.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: VVe eaſily beleeve it,
Though you ſhould ſpeak none elſe beſides your Native.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Pray ſtand you by, and wait a while.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: VVe obey.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Now will they think the better of us; 'tis
The way to bring our ſelves in Credit by
Neglecting of 'em thus. I'd have 'em know
VVe were to be ſaluted at their coming.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Their State is very unhappy, that it is
So unprovided: I beleeve theſe are
The very wiſeſt in the Kingdom; for
They have no Manners.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You gueſs rightly, Madam;
The greateſt Counſellors and Lawyers ſcarce
Know how to make a Leg.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: ARm, arm, arm, arm,
The King, and Lords are within ſight. Here Madam,
Pray take my Sword, and Helmet.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Worthy Gentlemen,
Doy' come to proffer aid from th' Cretan King
To help us 'gainſt the Men?

sp.speaker: Irin.
sp.l: No Ladies: we
Come but to tell you that the King is Landed,
We are your fellow-Subjects.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Fellow-Villaines
Among your ſelves. Eumela, we may thank
You for all this.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But Siſter of the Sword,
Great Lady Stickler—

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Be patient pray y' a while—Take you this Helmet,
And you this Fauchion Sir, and you this Lance;
Embaſſadours ſtill muſt be diſmiſs'd with Preſents.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Where is our Plate?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Our Wealth?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Our Jewels?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Folly!
Did not my Order bind me to aſſiſt
Diſtreſſed men?

sp.speaker: Coſ
sp.l: Who would e'r truſt a VVoman?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: The Queen will give y' a fair account.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: 'Tis no
Time to debate things now. The truth is, all
VVas ſhip'd, and ſent the King, as one great Preſent
From all the Cyprian VVomen. If you do
Deſire that he ſhould know how it was rais'd,
For what intended, by what means diverted,
I'l bid him ſpare his thanks, and tell him 'twas
Not Bounty, but Misfortune that directed
This vaſt Supply to him.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: We hope your Highneſs
Will be ſo Gratious to us, as to let us
Make the beſt uſe yet of our Evils. 'Twill
Be ſomething, if that, which was meant Sedition,
May now be took for Contribution,
And we eſteem'd Relievers of the Army.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I do engage my Royall word, you ſhall
Be put in th' Annals as good Members of
The Cyprian Commonwealth. But heark, the noiſe!
The Horſes, Trumpets, Prieſts! They come! ſtand off.

div.stage: To them 3 Prieſts of Apollo with wreaths of Lawrell, Demarchus and Dinomachus hand in hand, Paeſtanus, Philondas, Souldiers.

The Prieſts ſtanding on one ſide, and the Ladies on the other, leaving a free ſpace between 'em, in which Demarchus and Adraſte firſt meet. Then Dinomachus and Adraſte receive Chariſtus and Lucaſia; Then Philondas meets Malthora; Then the King and Queen joyn Olyndus and Eumela; The reſt then ſalutè, and receive one another with Welcome; While they all thus meet, the Prieſts on the one ſide, and the Ladies on the other, ſing thus enterchangeably.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt,
sp.l: APollo, who foretell'ſt what ſhall enſue,

l.hi: None ſpeaks more Dark than thou, but none More true;
If Heard, Obſcure; but yet if Seen, moſt Bright;
Day's in thy Viſage, in thy Sayings Night.
Day's in thy Viſage, in thy Sayings Night.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: Venus makes good what he Decrees,

l.hi: And Love ſulfils what he foreſees,
Thus Gods help Gods, thus Mortals ow
Much to the Bayes, much to the Bow.
Much to the Bayes, much to the Bow.

sp.speaker: 2 Prieſt.
sp.l: Phoebus as Praeſent ſhewes us future things,

l.hi: Our Trivets Counſell give, our Trees teach Kings,
And whil'ſt our Oracle inſtructs the State,
What e'r the Prieſt ſhall ſay the God makes Fate.
What e'r the Prieſt ſhall ſay the God makes Fate.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.

l.hi: What are your Trivets to Loves wings?
They Teach, but theſe do Conquer Kings:

sp.l: Venus to Fate adds all the bliſs,

l.hi: She that makes Doves, makes Kingdoms kiſs.
She that makes Doves makes Kingdoms kiſs.
Thus then the Myrtle and the Bayes we joyn.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: And in one Wreath Wiſdom and Love Combine.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I never raign'd till now. You needed not
Have ſent that Ample Treaſure; I had all
Wealth in your Loves. Come, Great Din • machus,
As they joyn'd Voices, ſo let us joyn Hearts.

sp.speaker: Dino.
sp.l: Sir, your Embraces vanquiſh far beyond
Your Sword, though happy; you march Conquerour
More by a Glorious Peace, than if your Arm
Had ſcatter'd Deaths ſtill as you paſs'd; your Throne
Grows hence; y'have gain'd what e'r you have not ruin'd;
Your Pow'r rules Cyprus, but your Fame the World.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Hate only is between th' Ignoble, when
The Good diſſent, tis only difference,
•• malice; Vertue flames in both, and ſo
•••… hmuſt the other Love; their Diſcords are
More blameleſs than th' Embraces of the Bad;
'Tis to ſtand off, rather than bear a Grudge.
And if they fight, when e'r they do lay down
Their VVeapons, they lay down their Anger too.
As we affect then to ſeem good, and are ſo,
Let one Oblivion wrap up what hath paſt
On either ſide.

sp.speaker: Dino.
sp.l: But I muſt firſt ask Pardon;
I've wrong'd a Deity. Great Apollo, be
Thou ſtill propitious. Here I do reſtore
Thy Blameleſs Prieſts. VVhat was but only Darkneſs,
I thought Contrivance; and the Prieſt not Loyall,
Becauſe the God was pleas'd to be obſcure:
But now th' Event lends light to that, and Me;
And my Chariſtus doth his Country ſave

l.hi: By being thus become his Enemi's Slave.

sp.l: Peace reſt upon 'em both; Apollo ſpoke it,
And Venus hath perform'd it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: As they joyn'd
To make us happy, ſo let us pay back
United Thanks, and joyn their Deities in
A double Feaſt. It is not Mens Lot only
To need each other; ev'n the Pow'rs themſelves
Give and take help. Affection brings about
VVhat Counſell cannot. Thus the Gods have lent
Love unto VViſdome for an Inſtrument.

lg.l: THough we well know the Neighbouring Plain
Can ſtrike from Reeds as high a Strain,
And that the Scrip, and Crook
May worſt our Poet's Book;
Like Fayries yet we here could ſtay
Till Village Cocks proclame the Day:
And whiles your Pleaſure is the Theam,
Feed and keep up the Dream.
But Sleep beginning now to ſhed
Poppies on every Bed,
Love ſtay'd his hands, and ſaid our Eyes
This Night were made his Prize:
And now (inſtead of Poppies) flings
Theſe wiſhes on you from his wings.
The Calm of Kingdoms new made Friends,
When both enjoy their Hopes, and Ends,
The like in you Create,
And make each Mind a State:
The thoughts of Princes, when they do
Meet Princes to coyn Princes too,
Poſſeſs your Breaſts with Fire and Youth,
And make each dream a Truth:
The Joyes of Friendſhip after Fight,
Of Love's firſt happy Night,
Of Lords return'd, make you ſtill greet,
As when you firſt did meet.
And, quitted thus from Grief and Fear,
Think you enjoy a Cyprus here.
